p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the fourth report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
The report read as follows—
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament
on 9 November 2022, 23 November 2022, 8 December 2022 and 25 January 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 51 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

From 2 petitioners—requesting legislation to control rent increases (EN4574)
From 55 petitioners—requesting the extradition of Julian Assange back to Australia (EN4577)

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following petitions:
Personal Information and Privacy
Google indexes personal information from 3rd party web sites and then can be spread on Facebook, Twitter etc.
Google are exposing personal privacy when searching an individual's name in the Google search engine.
Google should be capped/limited with particular Indexing from 3rd Party Web pages.
Google Engine should be limited form Government Web sites.

(Recommendation) Google Engine indexing can only expose the past 5 years of information from Government Web Pages, as some indexed information is over 10 years old, which continues to punish an individual with past minor offences.

Negatives>>>>>>> Indexing URLs from Government Web sites, does effect ones working career, causes slander on Facebook, Twitter, workplace rumor, people use this content to take advantage of people and causes mental stress.
Stop Google from Indexing URLS from Government Web Sites and then adding them into a Google search Engine, when searching your name...

We therefore ask the House to Stop Google from indexing from Government Web Sites and can only expose the past 5 years of information from Government Web Pages, as some indexed information is over 10 years old, which continues to punish an individual with past minor offences.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4573)
Housing

Real-estate has increased significantly. However Centrelink and Incomes doesn't. Rent is at a proportion similar to the value of property. Eg. If the house is $425,000 the rent is $425wk. Real-estate have a current ruling total applicants income is not to be 50% less their rent amount. Real-estate incentives such as NRAS give a large affordable discount however too many applicants.

We therefore ask the House to consider Real-estate Government Legislation that lets areas not all be property investment zones. And further consider the area of housing as housing governance in shires a priority if investors aren't motivated in this area. An example might be legislation that only allows a % increased annually.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4574)
Assange, Mr Julian Paul
As an Australian, Julian should be trialled and protected by Australia.
He is a journalist who speaks and highlights the truths in many countries and has been prosecuted for his freedom of speech and freedom of information.
His prosecution and involvement of the CIA sends a discomforting message for all Australian journalists and reporters and its citizens of Australia who deserve to see the truths in the world.
We therefore ask the House to extradite Julian Assange back to his home country.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. EN4577)
Disability Support Pension

Currently Australian citizens who have suffered significant and often permanent injuries from vaccines are required to undertake legal action against pharmaceutical companies to receive any form of compensation. This process can be long, expensive and unlikely to be successful, putting more stress on those who are already suffering both physically and mentally. Those who are no longer able to work have no source of income and are effectively punished if they have a partner who does work. Even a fairly average wage for a partner can cut DSP payments down to $0 and the financial pressures are immense when you have a family to support and a mortgage to pay.

Therefore it is time the very rare victims of significant vaccine injury (such as auto-immune diseases) are able to received adequate ongoing financial support given they had the vaccines in good faith to protect the wider community. If there is indeed to be 'no one left behind' in Australia, this policy needs to be introduced to replace the many years of lost income in the years ahead and ease the suffering of those who sacrificed their own health for the greater good.
We therefore ask the House to introduce an exemption to the Disability Support Pension income test for citizens who have suffered long-term disability due to injury via any TGA approved vaccine.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4578)
Skilled Migration Program
Due to technical issue, EN4306 petition was raised but closed without confirming that it is now approved for signatures. Therefore, raising another petition.

489 visa holders have already spent ~1,000 days (~1 year to get 489 visa and 2 years stay in regional area) to be eligible for 887 visa, however, even after being neglected during testing times of COVID, we kept going and contributed to Australia's economic recovery with limited job opportunities while being completely excluded from any form of assistance. The key issues facing us include a) Instability due to uncertainty, b) Lack of job opportunities—very few employers want to hire bridging visa holders because of lack of certainty, c) Kids still unsettled—887 visa applicants who have kids nearing University age must pay for international student fees, which in many cases can't be afforded. It ends up wasting crucial productive years of kids who could start university education without being held back as a result of 25 months processing time of 887 visa and d) Can't settle in Australia and plan ahead—887 visa applicants are treated as foreigners and therefore, unable to buy a house without FIRB approval and significant stamp duty.

We therefore ask the House to request Government to show MERCY and allow 887 visa applicants to come out of uncertainty by kindly allocating more Case Officers (currently <1) to clear backlog of onshore 887 visa applications (~20,000 pending) at par with resources allocated to process 190, 189, 491 visa.
from 5,270 citizens (Petition No. EN4581)
Cybercrime
With the ongoing theft of personal details by hackers, it is imperative that Australian Citizens are reassure by our government that their financial situation is protected by Law.

We therefore ask the House to , as a matter of urgency, shift the onus of responsibility to the lenders and credit providers that they are indeed dealing with an authentic loan or credit applicant. This will ensure that lenders and credit providers are diligent in investigating the authenticity of a loan or credit application. If the required legislative changes cannot be enacted in a timely manner, then we the undersigned request that lenders and credit providers be put on notice that the ensuing laws will be retrospective. The legislation can also include significant fines for lenders and credit providers that act irresponsibly with the provision of loans or credit to unauthenticated individuals. Other ways to ensure individual identities can be preserved, is to impose a government run, electronic triple factor identity authorisation system that provides lenders and credit providers a guaranteed way of authenticating a person's identity.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4582)
Disability Services

This petition calls for reform of the regulation of disabled parking by designating specific wheelchair accessible parking spaces separately to parking spaces to be used by ambulatory disabled persons. While people with all kinds of disability and mobility issues are entitled to park in designated disabled car parks across Australia, those in wheelchairs often cannot find a park. Their needs are additional to people who may be disabled but who are ambulatory. Many wheelchair users are simply unable to exit their vehicle unless a wheelchair accessible park is available, as they cannot open their door wide enough to get into their wheelchair in a standard parking space. Clearly, a dual level system is required to ensure that wheelchair users can access public spaces across Australia.

We therefore ask the House to reform the system which regulates disabled parking across Australia making it a requirement in all public places to include a number of wheelchair accessible car spaces as well as a number of designated car spaces for ambulatory disabled persons.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4583)
Pensions and Benefits
Many Australians are struggling below the poverty line. Current benefits available to low- and non-earners are insufficient, complicated and punitive.
Introducing a Universal Basic Income (UBI) at or above the poverty line would allow Australians to afford basic necessities such as food and accommodation.
This UBI could be paid for by measures like:

- simplifying the income tax system (for example, all earnings above the UBI could be taxed at 45c/dollar, the current highest tax rate. This would result in low- and middle-income earners getting more money overall and only be a minor reduction in net pay for high-income earners)
- eliminating or reducing other benefits which are exceeded by this UBI (for example, if UBI exceeds JobSeeker rates, JobSeeker will no longer be needed)

We therefore ask the House to introduce a UBI for all adult Australian citizens residing in Australia, with a pro-rata UBI for teenagers living with their parents. This UBI should be raised annually by at least the rate of CPI.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN4584)
MyGov

Cease the investigation into enforcing a digital ID onto the population via mygov. The current committee instigated by Bill Shorten is lead by a known digital proponent David Thodey. We must stop surveillance and population control which will eventuate via your digital ID system and consequent introduction of CBDCS. These must not be legislated. History shows things introduced as voluntary, soon become mandated.

Furthermore, rather than assisting in security of people's data, it is just another area for hackers to exploit. A digitised world has vulnerabilities and when the system goes down or is hacked, the consequences are dire.
We therefore ask the House to cease finding ways via mygov or other sources to enforce a digital ID. Keep it always a choice. Anything less is undemocratic.
from 1,798 citizens (Petition No. EN4588)
Human Rights: Iran
So many lives are taken on the streets of Iran just because they are asking for basic rights of living a normal life. Please help Iranians so this can be stopped before it's too many gone.

We therefore ask the House to hear Iranian people and assist people by putting pressure on Iranian's government, hold off any support they are receiving, in return requesting them releasing those who are in prison with no solid reason and stop cruelty on streets.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN4590)
World Economic Forum

Based in Switzerland, the World Economic Forum (WEF), a corporate-dominated, unelected, independent, non-governmental group that advocates for centralised, undemocratic power and global governance through environmental, economic, agricultural, technological, and education— climate change has also been weaponised by the WEF as a pretext for enacting the ideas of its "Great Reset" doctrine.

The WEF is able to push its progressive social agenda through deep partnerships and personnel overlap with the world's leading corporations relying on the private sector to implement WEF-sanctioned policies, including social credit scores and digital banking, government officials are also crucial to the group's mission.

The annual meeting in the Swiss luxury resort town Davos, routinely attracts the planet's top political officials, business leaders, media giants, and "thought leaders" including Nobel Prize laureates for speeches and panel discussions. This year's attendees included Bill Gates and former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger. Speakers through the years have advocated increased government control of the economic system or the environment.
Canada Alberta Premier Danielle Smith:
"Until that organisation [WEF] stops bragging about how much control they have over political leaders, I have no interest in being involved with them."
Australian taxpayers do not support the WEF's goals. NO REFERENDUM HELD.

We therefore ask the House to create a "The Defund Davos Act" (as was introduced in the USA House on August 26 as H. R. 8748), to ban federal funds from being used towards the World Economic Forum (WEF) and remove any ties to Australia including the "Global Lighthouse Network"
from 5,796 citizens (Petition No. EN4591)
Jammu and Kashmir

October 27 is observed as Kashmir Occupation Day to protest the forceful and illegal occupation of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) by the Indian Occupation Forces in 1947. On 5 August 2019, India suspended the special status of the J&K through the revocation of Articles 370 and 35-A followed by adopting measures to attempt to dilute the population of Kashmiris in the state.

Currently, there are over 900,000 Indian security personnel deployed for 8 million people of J&K. These forces routinely carry out extrajudicial killings in fake encounters, custodial tortures, enforced disappearances, and use other methods of subjugation with impunity. The HR violations have been extensively documented by the UN OHCHR and global media. The UN Secretary-General expressed his grave concern on the OHCHR report.
We therefore ask the House to call on India to:
• Respect the UNSC resolutions which recognize Jammu and Kashmir as a "disputed territory" and call for the resolution of the issue "through the democratic method of a free and impartial plebiscite."
• Publicly raise the issue of human rights violations with the Indian leadership.
• Call on India to reverse the illegal actions of 5 August 2019 and the so-called delimitation of Jammu and Kashmir.
• Accept the OHCHR's Reports and recommendations on J&K
• Immediately release all incarcerated Kashmiri political leaders, social-activists, rights-defenders, journalists, teenagers, and others detained under PSA or false criminal charges.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4592)
Arts and Culture

Australia is one of the few English-speaking nations without a publicly funded and appointed Poet Laureate. In addition to raising the profile of poetry, literature and the arts, such a figure would make a unique and valuable contribution to our national discourse.
In accordance with global practice, the Poet Laureate should be renewed annually or biennially, and provided a stipend to fully support their creative activity through their tenure.

The Laureate should be given the freedom to shape and develop the position with minimal guidelines. Global experience shows that Laureate can help to create a new cultural space within our national public sphere, giving voice to marginalised cultures and modalities of thought.
We therefore ask the House to establish the office of Australian Poet Laureate, to be administered by the National Library of Australia.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4593)
Skilled Migration Program

As part of the Population package announced in the 2019-2020 Budget, two new regional visas were introduced to encourage new skilled migrants to settle in regional areas. The holders of these provisional skilled regional visas are required to live and work in a regional area for at least three years before they are eligible for a permanent visa.
Currently, the 491 and 494 visa holders are disadvantaged compared to holders of permanent skilled visas available for people to work in metropolitan areas.
As such, they are not entitled to any government services and are subject to the additional foreign citizen stamp duty upon purchase of a residential property.

We therefore ask the House to revisit and amend the 'New Skilled Regional Visas (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2019' by giving effect to Government policy that enables the holders of provisional skilled regional visas to have access to welfare payments or government services, where eligible, and be exempt from the additional foreign tax when acquiring residential property, as if they are holders of permanent visas.
This recognises that the provisional skilled regional visas provide a pathway to permanent residence and contribute to the Australian economy in the same way permanent residents do.

These new arrangements will allow the 491 and 494 visa holders to further support Australian economy and will be life altering for many families genuinely willing to settle, invest in a property and contribute to the regional Australia growth.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4598)
Migration: Housing

The Australian Government has recently increased the FIRB (Foreign Investment Review Board) price from $5,700 to $13,200, Which is too much for some people really want to stay and live and work in regional areas.
We work hard every day to contribute to this country and pay the same tax as everyone in Australia but unfortunately, I can't afford $13,200 + 7-8% extra Foreign Citizen Stamp Duty.

I am starting this petition hoping that the Australian Government will see how people straggling this is and please cancel this fee or at least make it more affordable for regional visa holders so that more people can live in regional areas without breaking the bank! We are not asking for free handouts but just fair access to opportunities like everyone else.
We therefore ask the House to should:
1) Regional Visa Holders should not pay FIRB Fees and only 4-5% stamp duty as they are growing in regional areas of Australia which need more people to stay.

2) The Australian Government needs to review this unfair policy immediately as it will discourage people stays in regional areas of Australia which are very important for our country's growth and prosperity!
3) We would like to see the government encourage more people in rural/regional areas of Australia rather than discouraging it with policies such as these.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4599)
Australian Curriculum

According to the latest census data in Australia, Punjabi is the fastest growing language in Australia and one of the top 5 languages to be spoken at home. Punjabi has also emerged as the most popular Indian sub-continent language.
Here are the state-wise figures for Punjabi speakers in Australia.
• VICTORIA—104,949
• QUEENSLAND—30,873
• WESTERN AUSTRALIA—20,613
• SOUTH AUSTRALIA—20,004
• AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ACT)—5,019
• TASMANIA—2,556
• NORTHERN TERRITORY—1,563
The Punjabi community in Australia needs their language to be included in the P-10 national curriculum.

Punjabi language will enable the Indian heritage children to understand Punjabi culture & learn from older generations. People who speak more than one language have improved memory, problem-solving and critical-thinking skills, enhanced concentration, ability to multitask, and better listening skills.
It would greatly benefit the Punjabi community if Punjabi language is included in the national P-10 curriculum.

We therefore ask the House to instruct the Education Minister's office and ACAARA (Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority) to start the work on incorporating the inclusion of Punjabi language in the national curriculum.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4600)
Asylum Seekers
Inhumane treatment of asylum seekers
We therefore ask the House to cancel the temporary protection visas and give the asylum seekers a permanent protection visas after waiting for 10 years
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN4601)
Iran: Migration

Following the death in custody of Mahsa Amini on 16 September 2022, protests in Iran have continued to flare with government forces using lethal force against their own citizens. Media reporting indicates protestor deaths (including children) to be in the hundreds with further bloodshed expected. The Iranian government's crackdown is also seeing the arrest and detention of thousands of individuals. Government officials are conducting raids on homes, seizing personal electronic devices and arresting individuals on the basis of false allegations related to organising or participating in demonstrations. Individuals are being held in custody, including at the notorious Evin Prison, where they are likely to be subject to mistreatment and sham charges brought against them. Time is of the essence for many Iranian visa applicants with a decision on their application pending. Adding to the pressure of the situation are concerns that safe passage out of Iran for successful applicants may be impacted should the protests and government response escalate. The safety and security of these individuals is at risk, and it is an avoidable tragedy if they were to suffer further harm while their visa application is being considered.
We therefore ask the House to:
1. prioritise and expedite visa processing for Iranian applicants, in particular those who reside in Iran, and
2. enable special visa pathways to Iranian applicants who currently reside in Australia, in order for them to remain in Australia at this time.
from 164 citizens (Petition No. EN4602)
Child Abuse

The Royal Commission into Child Sex Abuse did address some of the issues in sport however since then there have been multiple revelations of sex abuse by elite Swimming Coaches. Victims have been unable to access redress even though Swimming Australia eventually signed up because the terms of eligibility state the abuse must have occurred on National teams. Most victims I have encountered were in State or local Swimming teams when the abuse occurred so they get no support or redress even when the offender has been found guilty. It is clear the gymnastics athletes are in the same situation. Several Olympians have suicided and thanks to the media several coaches have been arrested but Swimming Australia and the Sports Integrity Commission often hadn't acted despite multiple notifications from athletes being made. The policies have flaws and sport won't be cleaned up until those flaws are addressed. Many athletes didn't share their stories at the Royal Commission so the systemic issues from grass roots sport to elite sport were not even addressed. We need a commission of enquiry into historic and current sex abuse in all sports in order to fix the broken system.
We therefore ask the House to consider a Royal Commission into ALL abuse in ALL sports.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4603)
Skilled Migration Program
In July 2022, reports showed there were approximately 6500 vacancies in the Early Childhood Education and Care Sector across Australia.
Jobs data indicates that staff shortages in the sector are likely to increase. The Australian Government predicted in 2019 that an additional 39,600 early childhood educators will be needed by 2024.

The sector faces big challenges in attracting and retaining staff. This creates issues of being able to adequately staff services to ensure they can remain open and operational, but also high staff turnover and stressed educators, which impacts children and families.

For overseas students seeking a visa to study in Australia, Early Childhood Education and Care is a popular choice, and our sector is lucky to have them. However, once we have trained them, and having invested time, resources and financial support, they are often left with no option but to leave the sector in order to study another course to retain their student visa status, or they have to return home.

These educators offer so much that enhances early childhood education and care settings. Their culture, language, traditions, customs, experiences and perspectives add to the rich, quality, early learning environments that we are able to offer children.

We therefore ask the House to make the pathway for the international students studying ECEC, easier for them to stay permanently in the Country and continue to positively contribute to our sector, by reinstating the role of Early Childhood Educator (Child Care worker) on the list for the 190 and 482 class visas.
from 100 citizens (Petition No. EN4604)
Pensions and Benefits

Partner income being used to affect an individual's welfare status is dangerous. It has been pointed out consistently by domestic violence advocacies as a reason people are unable to escape from abuse. It also unreasonably causes households to collapse under the pressure of not being able to afford the most basic necessities such as rent and utilities without extreme sacrifices that lead to further disadvantage.
Households with an income <$100,000/yr struggle immensely.
Example, jobseeker:
Partner: works 38/hrs, $22/hr = $1,672/ftnt.
Penalty: partner earns > $1196/ftnt = lose $53 + $0.60 per $1 over $1196.
Maximum partnered jobseeker: $608.70

That $276.70/ftnt has to pay your share of the rent, utilities, food, clothing, broken appliances, fuel, rego, license renewals, bond for rentals, medical expenses, pet expenses, insurance expenses etc.
Household: $50,666.20/yr
Partner: earns => $2,223.67/ft
Penalty: partner earns => $2,223.67/ftnt = ineligible.
You: $0/ftnt
Household: $57,8152.42/yr
Rent: $450/wk average = $23,400/yr
Per person: $11,700/yr
almost half of the household income.
At years end, $4,505.80 would be owed to your partner for your share of the rent that you were not able to cover. This does not factor in medical, food, utilities, or any other kind of expense.
We therefore ask the House to completely scrap the use of partner income penalizing ALL individual Centrelink benefits.
from 200 citizens (Petition No. EN4606)
MyGovID
Many government rebates and entitlements are now only delivered to small and medium sized enterprises through MyGovID.

The problem is that MyGovID simply doesn't work. This enable the government to claim that they have made all these rebates and offers to business but simply do not follow through by slamming the door shut in sabotaging MyGovID.
We therefore ask the House to ensure that MyGovID is overhauled and made simple and workable to small and medium sized enterprises.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4607)
Vaccination
Recent releases on safety data have shown not only do the mRNA vaccines not work in any manner, they also were not tested and the adverse side effects were known beforehand.
These contracts were signed without the full disclosure of these facts and therefore should be considered null and void.
Australia and the Australian people have been conned out of billions of dollars for a vaccine that does not stop the spread or protect the person who has had it.
Lives have been ruined in one form or another as a result and victims of this scam should be able to have some justice against big pharma.
We therefore ask the House to revoke protection for the companies on the grounds they lied and covered up the facts. To allow those injured to be freed to pursue legal recourse.
from 1,557 citizens (Petition No. EN4610)
HomeBuilder

The HomeBuilder grant does not recognise that for apartments / strata developments, certificate of title is not issued until construction is complete, compared with single-tier developments where title is issued at the start of the construction process. Furthermore, no sunset date for the submission of all documents was in place when the scheme was initially announced, and was only implemented after many people had already entered into contracts for these strata developments. The Government recognised the widespread delays in the construction industry by extending the deadline to commence construction from 3 to 18 months, but did not extend the deadline for submission of title accordingly. In many cases this has been further exacerbated by construction companies going into administration, causing further significant delays in construction. The Government claims to seek to address the housing affordability crisis and stagnation in the construction industry, but the inaction in extending the deadline for submission of documentation to maintain eligibility for this grant suggests otherwise.
We therefore ask the House to extend the deadline for submission of documentation for the HomeBuilder grant by 6 months to 30 October 2023.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4611)
Asylum Seekers

People living in Australia on Bridging Visas are being denied the opportunity to study or work once they turn 18 years old. The Department of Immigration officers are applying inconsistent "policy" denying people seeking asylum the opportunity to work or study while living in Australia.

This means when some asylum seekers reach the age of 18, they have no further opportunity for study (some having already commenced tertiary study) and are prevented by their visas terms from seeking employment.

We therefore ask the House to support whatever changes may be required to the HECS and other education legislation to allow the Minister for Immigration to address this inconsistent approach to Bridging Visas (BVEs) to include study and work rights as a matter of course when granting the visas.
from 225 citizens (Petition No. EN4612)
Asylum Seekers

The prolonged detention of asylum seekers and refugees is contrary to Article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, inflicted due to seeking protection from Australia, being inflicted because of seeking to exercise the right under Article 14 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to seek protection. The indefinite prolonged detention is torture and cruel punishment for seeking asylum in Australia by boat, designed to deter people from coming to Australia, and is torture under the United Nations Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. There was no consideration of alternatives to detention and this prolonged detention is in breach of article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The imposition of intolerable conditions and duration of detention, including unsafe conditions of detention, has had severe impacts on the asylum seekers and refugees physical and mental health. There have been deaths in detention, and there are asylum seekers and refugees who have irrevocable damage to their health from Australia's asylum seeker policy. Australia's asylum seekers policy ((The Migration Legislation Amendment (Offshore Processing and Other Measures) Bill 2011, Migration Amendment (Unauthorised Maritime Arrivals and Other Measures) Act 2013 (Cth), Migration Legislation Amendment (Regional Processing and Other Measures) Act 2012 (Cth) s 25)) must change to include compassion and to respect and protect human rights.
We therefore ask the House to change Australia's asylum seekers policy; to end offshore processing and end indefinite detention of people seeking asylum by boat.
from 456 citizens (Petition No. EN4613)
Human Rights: Eritrea and Tigray

The conflicts in northern Ethiopia have caused one of the world's worst humanitarian crises with wider-scale atrocities against civilians including Eritrean refugees. the huge involvement of Eritrea in the conflict has caused unimaginable deaths, unmediated violence, destruction, and displacement to the people of Tigray, including the vulnerable Eritrean refugees who are caught in the crossfire. At the same, the ongoing gross human rights violations in Eritrea which have been exacerbated by the involvement of the totalitarian regime of Isaias Afewerki in the internal conflict in Ethiopia caused the human tragedy in Eritrea. We are deeply concerned by the significant roundups and conscription of children as young as 15 and adults as old as 70 years, including sick and disabled persons, who are forcibly sent by the Eritrean Government to the war in Tigray.

The recent peace agreement between the Ethiopian federal force and the Tigray Liberation Front (TPLF) on November 2, 2022, in South Africa, is a potential breakthrough for peace in the country. However. adequate peace in northern Ethiopia and protection of the Eritrean refugees is a long road ahead due to the continued infiltration of the Eritrean forces in Tigray.

We therefore ask the House to consider the humanitarian situation in Eritrea and northern Ethiopia (Tigray) and play important role in the implementation of the peace agreement in Ethiopia that include among others immediate cessation of hostilities and opening of humanitarian corridors.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4617)
Migration

The Penuela Castillo family is being hard done by. They are being forced to leave Australia on November 17, 2022 because Cesar's Penuela employer failed to comply with the employment letter of offer and visa procedures.

The family of Cesar, his wife Claudia and their two daughters, Maria Jose, aged 14, and Janah, 7 (born in Australia), have lived here for 13 years. He received an offer of employment that included a commitment from his employer to sponsor them under the Regional Business Sponsorship Program. Cesar undertook extensive English study, furthered his qualifications and moved to Launceston to meet all immigration and work requirements. He discovered that his employer, despite repeated requests, refused to submit the necessary documents to the Department of Home Affairs and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Cesar's visa application was therefore rejected only because of his employer, not the family.

They are hard-working, good people who bring much to our community. Since 2019, Claudia has worked in age care and provided care to the elderly during COVID-19. Cesar is a qualified graphic artist who has a new job lined up in Launceston. They are both dedicated Vinnies volunteers, feeding the homeless in Launceston. Their daughters know Australia as their home, are thriving at school and in their sporting clubs.

We therefore ask the House to let them stay to sort their visas. On 16 November 2022, the regional provisional stream of the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) visa (subclass 191) commences, they qualify and would apply for this visa.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN4618)
Human Rights: Eritrea and Tigray
This petition is in support of the peaceful demonstration in front of the Parliament House on November 9, 2022 and a letter send to the PM of Australia.

We, Australian citizens of Eritrean origin from all over Australia, appeal to the Australian Government to use all its diplomatic means and continue playing its important role in joining the growing voices of the international community to call on the Eritrean Government to respect the UN Charter, uphold its human rights responsibilities, end forced indefinite conscription, release hundreds of conscripted children, political prisoners, prisoners of conscience and religious leaders, including persons imprisoned for their religious beliefs.
We therefore ask the House to

support the peace process chaired by African Union and influence the implementation of the peace agreement reached that include among others immediate cessation of hostilities and opening of humanitarian corridor to all areas of Tigray and the region, and demand respect of human right by all parties.
call for Ethiopian troops to leave Eritrea and Eritrean troops to withdraw from Tigray, northern Ethiopia immediately.
call for the Eritrean Government to answer where abouts of over 20,000 Eritrean refugees remain unknown.

consider special humanitarian intake of Eritreans refugees in the conflict zone in Ethiopia for resettlement in Australia, as many Eritrean Australians are so worried about the safety of their family members in the region.
call for an independent investigation of crime against humanity during the war in Tigray and perpetrators brought to justice.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4619)
Human Rights: Pakistan

There is huge human rights violations ongoing in Pakistan. The people are been tortured and killed without any justification by government and agencies in fact private videos of parents are sent to their children's, which is a shame. Few major events in recent month are, assassination of a well know journalist Arshad Shareef (who criticized them), assassination attempt on ex PM Imran Khan (who also is opposition), senators private videos were sent to his daughter and many people and journalists are abducted / trapped in fake cases and never returned.
We therefore ask the House to put demarche to Pakistan ambassador and request to stop violation of human rights immediately.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4621)
Nicotine Vaping Products

Despite the illegality of the sale of nicotine vapes to the general public, vapes are a serious problem to public health. Vapes contain harmful chemicals that can lead to lung cancer, high blood pressure and increased chance of a variety of chronic illnesses. Vapes are a gateway to smoking cigarettes for young people, with increasingly more students partaking in vaping as a result of peer pressure, stress relief and lack of risk perception. Vapes are just as, if not more harmful than cigarettes.
We therefore ask the House to ban the harmful chemicals used in vapes. These include but are not limited to; flavourants (diacetyl, etc.), nicotine, heavy metals, and ultra fine particles.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN4624)
Australian Constitution

Republicanism in Australia is a movement to change Australia's system of government from a constitutional parliamentary monarchy to a republic, replacing the monarch of Australia (currently Charles III) with a president. We as Australians, truly support the move of Australia to become a republic, in-line with Anthony Albanese MP's motives.
We therefore ask the House to make a government reform, transitioning into a republic government and leave the Commonwealth.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4626)
Health Care
The Govt's responses to Covid-19 was disproportionate to the actual risks involved, now we have the benefit of hindsight.
The Oz Govts were gripped by Mass Formation thinking, causing significantly more harm than the virus itself.
We therefore ask the House to Call for a national Public Inquiry into a better way for Parliament/Govt to handle future health pandemics.
To assist, the book 'The Psychology of Totalitarianism' by Mattias Desmet defines Mass Formation.
from 180 citizens (Petition No. EN4629)
Medicare

Autoimmune conditions are not currently recognised under this scheme. There is now increasing evidence that covid vaccines causes autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes. The government needs to recognise this add all autoimmune conditions to the scheme. The government also needs to make scheme easier to apply for and not need a medical letter. As no doctor is willing to write the vaccine definitely caused the condition.
We therefore ask the House to fix the scheme and make it easier to apply for.
from 105 citizens (Petition No. EN4631)
Human Rights: Iran

The Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) is a terrorist organisation. They murder and torture civilians to keep them quiet from expressing the truth of the corrupt governing bodies in Iran. The same governing bodies and the IRGC are responsible for aiding in the attack against Ukraine and murdering innocent civilians. Since the murder of Mahsa Jina Amini, 22-year-old Iranian-Kurdish women, protests have erupted across the globe. The true Iranian people are not represented by the Islamic Republic, we do not recognise or accept being categorized under this terrorist organisation.
We therefore ask the House to
1. CLOSE AND SHUT DOWN THE ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF IRAN'S EMBASSY IN CANBERRA
2. Deport Islamic republic diplomats that are affiliated with the Islamic Republic and advocates for the IRGC and revoke their visas, reject any future individuals apart of this regime
3. Freeze assets of the Islamic Republic of Iran and the IRGC here in Australia
4. Recognise affiliates of the IRI and the IRGC as terrorists
5. Apply Sanctions on IRI and the IRGC
from 530 citizens (Petition No. EN4632)
Housing
social housing is known by the way it appears on our streets—awful most the time—(visually)
we need to improve the social housing to a standard that where citizens start to talk about how lucky underprivileged citizen of Australia really are
this standard will set a benchmark for all other housing in the surrounding areas and improve the value of homes along the way
we have to stop cramming so many units onto the one block, along with the internal living areas of these units, are almost inhumane to live in
if we spend a touch more, we will thrive a touch more
the general public would be impressed with these efforts and thrive in knowing about the quality and value coming to their Neiborhood if a social housing project was coming their way in the future
better design better results—we need the underprivilege people to fall in love with their accommodation options and one day they may have the choice of owning the dwelling
We therefore ask the House to create a Volume 4 to the NCC (National Construction Code) that relates Soley to the Social Housing
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4633)
Waste Management and Recycling

The petitioners draw the parliament's attention to the announcement that RedCycle has paused accepting soft plastic recycling indefinitely. RedCycle is the main way that average Australians can recycle soft plastics via supermarkets. This means that the only alternative for many Australians is to direct their soft plastic waste to landfill. This means that Australians pick up the bill through landfill fees and litter whilst the major supermarkets, retailers and manufacturers profit from using excessive soft plastic packaging.

We therefore ask the House to consider funding or supporting soft plastic recycling and explore the methods of making this sustainable, for example, via a soft plastic levy or deposit scheme on soft plastic packaging.
from 59 citizens (Petition No. EN4634)

subdebateinfo.title: Food and Grocery Industry: Australian Owned Produce

p.span: Food and Grocery Industry: Australian Owned Produce

Almost 90 percent of Australians have said it's important to see their dollars go back into our economy. So why then are a large majority of our supermarket shelves being taken up by foreign owned products?
Australian owned products are being squeezed out. And if we don't do something about it, the estimated 15 percent of Australian owned products in our supermarkets will soon diminish.

Australian retailers are not held accountable for providing equal opportunity to promote Australian owned products with the result that, foreign owned brands with deeper pockets and stronger financial power, are quietly pushing Australian owned businesses out.

While a voluntary code of conduct exists, supermarkets aren't beholden to it when it comes to Australian owned. We need to change this by introducing a mandatory statute that has the power to provide equal opportunity for existing Australian owned products and encourage the innovation of new locally owned products through entrepreneurship. It exists in other industries so the same needs to apply to the food and grocery sector before it's too late.
We therefore ask the House to e establishment of a mandatory statute, to ensure the strength and diversity of Australian owned products within the food and grocery sector for years to come.

Unless there is a voluntary acceptance, we need the introduction of a mandatory statute that stipulates: "Food and grocery retailers are required to demonstrate significant effort to highlight, in each product category, Australian owned brands and where possible, also provide prominent and preferential shelf space allocation".
from 3,726 citizens (Petition No. EN4636)
Pensions and Benefits

Australia needs teachers. To teach in Victoria, for example, a master's level qualification is required. To be accepted into such courses a student must have two modes of instruction which, in many cases, will require two degrees prior to embarking on the education-based course. A Master of Teaching or Master of Applied Learning and Teaching should be an acceptable course of training that attracts the JSP given that they are skillsets that are required by both the industry and the nation. Furthermore, Austudy should not be considered by any government as an acceptable payment for those that put themselves forward to be educators.

We therefore ask the House to amend s 613 of the Social Security Act 1991 (Cth) to exempt full time study in courses that, at the end of which, the graduate is eligible to be admitted into teaching by their state's regulating body.
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN4637)
Australian Currency
As Australian citizens we should be concerned about the disadvantages of a Central Bank Digital Currency.
Traceability:
In the case where physical cash is eliminated entirely this eliminates our ability to transact in a fully anonymous manner.
Negative Rates:
With CBDCs, you cannot withdraw your digital tokens and hold them under the mattress. If there is no option for physical cash this gives central banks ability to implement negative interest rates.
Programmability:
CBDCs give central banks a unique opportunity to make money "programmable".

For example: Expiration, with a direct relationship with your central bank, CBDCs could permit a currency expiration policy. Your money could be programmed so that if you don't spend the $5000 in your account by next Saturday, it will expire.
Personalised monetary policy:
With a bank of Big Data on individual spending habits, coupled with digital identification infrastructure, the central bank will have enough information to tailor its monetary policy personally.
For example if it is known that lower earners have a higher propensity to consume, stimulus can be directly delivered to those people.
Personalised monetary policy could even become politicised. A government could segment its voters, identify communities where it is behind in polls, and deliver stimulus to these groups.
We therefore ask the House to enshrine the use of cash in law.
from 119,048 citizens (Petition No. EN4638)
Human Rights: Iran

The Government of Islamic Republic of Iran is using unprecedented violence against unarmed and peaceful protestors who are demanding justice for Mahsa Amini (RIP) and guarantees of basic human rights for all Iranian citizens.

We therefore ask the House to move a motion for the Foreign Minister to summon the Islamic Republic's ambassador and demand immediate cessation of government sponsored violence against all Iranian citizens especially, women. We also ask that House to move a motion for appropriate ministries to investigate large investments made by Iranian officials and/or their proxies in Australian and freeze such assets until all current and future sanctions against the Islamic Republic have been removed.
from 105 citizens (Petition No. PN0549)
Human Rights: Iran

The government of the Islamic republic of Iran uses torture, illegal imprisonment and live ammunition against its own citizens especially innocent young women, men, and children who ae demanding nothing but their very basic human rights.

We therefore ask the House to take whatever action that is necessary to:- 1. Condemn the Government of Islamic Republic 2. Sever diplomatic relations with the Islamic republic and expel Islamic Republic's ambassador and officials. 3. Deny vias to all Islamic Republic officials and their relatives and proxies to enter Australia. 4. Investigate financial and money-laundering networks of the Islamic Republic in Australia. 5. Identify and freeze assets held by official of the Islamic Republic and their proxies and corporate vehicles in Australia. 6. Enact Magnitsky sanctions against key actors and members of Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), the Basji militia and the Officials of the Islamic Republic and their proxies. 7. Remove the government of Islamic republic of Iran from the UN Commission on the status of Women. 8. Support the people of Iran by providing incentives to telecommunication companies to deliver free internet access in Iran. 9. Provide humanitarian ais to families affected by government violence in Iran through NGO's. 10. Encourage elected representatives to attend protests organised by the Australian Iranian communities in their constituencies showing support for protesters and condemning government violence.
from 641 citizens (Petition No. PN0550)
Waste Management and Recycling

Due to the increasing demand of consumer products there has been an equal rise in non biodegradable soft plastic waste. With the Redcycle system that Australians were using combat this issue now on an indefinite hold, the waste from the enormous amount of products using soft plastics has no where to go now but the already over full dumps. With climate change such a pressing issue for everyone, getting rid of single use plastic bags is not going far enough. To push change for the better, industry must find a new solution to the use of soft non biodegradable plastics. This won't solve the problem of climate change on its own but it will be a step forward in the right direction.
We therefore ask the House to force industry to make the change to using biodegradable soft plastics only to reduce waste and our impact on the planet.
from 175 citizens (Petition No. EN4640)
Coeliac Disease: Defence Recruitment

The Australian Defence Force does not allow people with Coeliac disease to enlist in the military. A document titled; Food Allergies and Australian Combat Ration Packs released by the Department of Defence/Defence Science and Technology Organisation states "Food Intolerance, including Coeliac disease, Class 4—Permanently medically unfit for military service." Their reasoning behind this is that over half of the foods in MREs (meal, ready-to-eat) contain gluten, with this gluten accounting for a high percentage of the energy and nutritional values, leading them to believe that someone with Coeliac disease or a gluten allergy would become malnourished. This is absurd as we know that the Australian Defence Force can alter catering towards feeding people in the military as they made a third of their MREs Halal certified, along with kosher and vegetarian options. With this in mind, making a minority of MREs gluten-free while replacing the nutritional and energy values is definitely doable due to advancements in food technology today.

We therefore ask the House to overlook and revise the employment regulations that are in place that stop people with Coeliac disease from joining the ADF. We also understand why these rules are in place. Still, we firmly believe that these regulations can be amended so that if someone with Coeliac disease or a gluten allergy wants to join the military they should understand the risks and have to accept what could happen to them. We ask the respective ministers to propose a solution that will benefit everybody.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4641)
Illicit Drugs

The war on drugs has not worked, people will do them no matter what. So we are better off treating it as a health issue and not a criminal issue. Regulating the market instead of leaving it in the hands of crime organizations and tax profits
We therefore ask the House to
1. Legalize the sale and consumption of all drugs for people over the age of 18
2. Ban Advertising of 'Dangerous' Drugs
3. Regulate the industry
4. Tax the industry
5. Defund police efforts towards prosecution
6. Fund rehabilitation centers, safe use programs, and education
7. Release all prisoners convicted of non-violent drug crimes
from 109 citizens (Petition No. EN4642)
Medicare: Mental Health

31st December 2022 will mark the end of the program that allowed eligible patients to access 10 additional subsidised individual psychological therapy sessions per calendar year under the existing Better Access to Psychiatrists, Psychologists and General Practitioners through the MBS (Better Access) initiative.

Previously, Australians were only able to access a maximum of ten sessions under the MBS. This arbitrary number of sessions didn't even allow individuals to see their therapists once a month and fails to reflect an individual's treatment needs. Under the Federal Government's COVID-19 initiative, the number of psychology sessions a person can access via Medicare in a calendar year was increased to 20. Many Australians from a diverse range of backgrounds have benefited greatly from this initiative, being accessed by over 2 million Australians in 2022 alone.

Ten sessions are not enough for someone living with mental health issues. Australian research has found that to obtain improved outcomes, 70% of clients required over 20 sessions of therapy (Harnett et al, 2010). The 20 session program costs just over 1% of the total spend per annum on mental health-related services, and the Productivity Commission has also found that small and targeted investment would improve the federal budget through cost savings of $18bn per year in forgone health, social and judicial expenses.
All Australians deserve access to affordable mental health care.
We therefore ask the House to make Medicare-subsidised 20 psychology sessions a permanent change. This will provide certainty for people with mental health concerns.
from 20,664 citizens (Petition No. EN4643)
Skilled Migration Program

494 visa application processing time has been taking longer than usual. It hasn't been given any priority or look into the visa application of any other skilled workers rather than hospital sector. We humbly request you to please have a look/ review/ give a priority it needs and process the application less than the estimated time that has been changing every time from 8 months to 12 months. We have been waiting for so long and there hasn't been any updates/ news for 494 visa. 494 visa is also one of the visa that will help economic changes in regional area and development of the country. We all applicants of 494 visa has been waiting in dark just waiting to get good news.
Thank you

We therefore ask the House to Process the 494 visa application to be processed to be reviewed and processed earlier than estimated time which is 365 days and have been waiting more than 6 months already.
Thank you
from 53 citizens (Petition No. EN4645)
Australian Currency

Australia's currency has always featured representations of our monarch, firstly on coins and more recently on notes. It is now a well-established practice that the image of our reigning monarch appears on the $5 note. King Charles III has acceded to the throne and is King of Australia, and so should appear on our Australian currency. The minting of the King's effigy on our currency will not only represent the beginning of a new era, but also the special relationship between His Majesty and the Australian people.

We therefore ask the House to ensure that the Commonwealth Government (including the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Royal Australian Mint) causes the King's image to be included on the Australian $5 note, and his effigy on the obverse of all Australian coins, as soon as practicable.
from 59 citizens (Petition No. EN4646)
Defence

We deplore the plan by the United States and the Australian government to deploy six nuclear-capable B-52 bombers to the Tindal Air Base near Darwin because it makes Australia a base for potential US military strikes on China as part of a broader US-led war against China.
This is despite the absence of any credible evidence that China plans to invade Taiwan, or instigate military aggression anywhere.

During the Richard Nixon administration, China agreed to seek peaceful reunification with Taiwan, in return for the US recognising that Taiwan is part of China and refraining from supporting any move to formally declare Taiwanese independence.
Australia's official position is also that Taiwan is part of China, and that there should be no unilateral move to change the current situation.

Recent US actions, including repeated threats of military action by President Joe Biden, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan, undermine the commitment to the status quo, as does the B-52 plan for Tindal.
Canberra is a willing accomplice.
We therefore ask the House to cancel:
the stationing of B52 bombers in the Northern Territory, the AUKUS Pact; and the Marine Rotational Force—Darwin.

Further, we call on the Australian government to adhere to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which Australia signed in 1970, and to sign the United Nations Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons.
from 458 citizens (Petition No. EN4647)
First Nations Australians: Child Protection

The Family Matters Report 2022, released by SNAICC-National Voice for our Children, reveals that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children continue to be removed from their families at increasing rates, impacting on current and future generations.

Nationally, data continue to demonstrate that current systems for child protection are not equipped to meet the commitment of Target 12 of the National Agreement on Closing the Gap to reduce the over-representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in out-of-home care by 45 per cent by 2031.

A staggering 22,297 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children were in out-of-home care at 30 June 2021. They are 10.4 times more likely than non-Indigenous children to be in out-of-home care, and this trend is expected to increase by 50 per cent over the next decade.
The Family Matters Report 2022 presents a range of recommendations, primarily focused on empowering Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and organisations.

We therefore ask the House to establish a National Commissioner for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children, independent from governments with powers to investigate and report publicly on issues affecting our children. We request a Commissioner to give a dedicated focus on their rights, investigate systemic barriers to transforming child protection, ensuring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children thrive into the future. A Commissioner would support strategies for more effective collaboration, breaking down bureaucratic silos, and drive systemic reform to turn the tide of over-representation in the child protection system.
from 510 citizens (Petition No. EN4648)
Pedestrian and Bicycle Infrastructure

Australia is ridden with cars, and traffic. We have tried adding more lanes to "fix" traffic but the only way to fix traffic is for less people on the road. Get the people on the road onto safe and protected pathways, and bike lanes. This can also help with the obesity epidemic creating more fit Aussies.
Businesses report higher sales in areas with more pedestrian access, and these areas are seen as more desirable.
We therefore ask the House to recognize the importance of pedestrian and bike infrastructure and the benefits it has on the economy and livability, and to provide more funding for such construction.
from 83 citizens (Petition No. EN4650)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4032, with 16 signatures, concerning the situation in Ukraine.
The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that Ukrainians in Australia can continue to reside in the Australian community with access to work, health, education and visa support services.
The Department of Home Affairs is progressing visa applications from Ukrainian nationals as a priority, particularly for those with a connection to Australia.

Almost 5,000 Ukrainian nationals and their families accepted the Government offer of a temporary humanitarian stay. The temporary humanitarian stay ensures that Ukraine nationals who have had to flee their country due to the Russian invasion have access to work and study for school-aged children, and gain access to Medicare and other relevant support services.

Since 23 February 2022, the Government has granted nearly 9,000, visas to Ukrainians in Ukraine and hundreds more to Ukrainians elsewhere. As at 31 July 2022, nearly 4,400 of these visa holders have since arrived in Australia.
Ukrainian nationals who were unable to accept the Government's offer of a Temporary Humanitarian Stay by 31 July 2022, can access other visa options:

Ukrainians and their families who wish to extend their stay in Australia or explore migration options can continue to access visa pathways, including through the Skilled, Family, Student and Visitor visa programs.
Ukrainians who are unable to access any further visa options or cannot return to Ukraine may apply for a Bridging E (subclass 050) visa or a Protection (subclass 866) visa.
Ukrainians are encouraged to explore what visa options are suitable for them via the Department's website at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-and-support/ukraine-visa-support.

The Government has provided additional funding of $550,000 to Ukrainian and other community organisations to facilitate their provision of support to Ukrainian nationals in Australia. This funding is in addition to $450,000 previously provided to the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations as part of the Government's commitment to supporting the international response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the humanitarian efforts to assist those fleeing the war.

Ukrainian Australians are an integral part of Australian society and community. The Government understands the concerns for family and friends in Ukraine, and acknowledges the continuing efforts of members of the Ukrainian Australian community to inform and support the Government's efforts to respond to this crisis.

The Government is endeavouring to do all it can to continue to assist those affected through its ongoing whole-of-government and collaborative efforts. I note the Petition's call for further humanitarian aid to Ukraine. As this matter falls outside of my portfolio responsibilities, I have copied this letter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Penny Wong.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4032 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4034, with 180 signatures, concerning Grant Humanitarian Aide and evacuation help to Ukrainian citizens.

The Department of Home Affairs is progressing visa applications from Ukrainian citizens as a priority, particularly for those with a strong, personal connection to Australia. Temporary visa applications to facilitate urgent travel are processed generally within days.

Since 23 February 2022, the Department has granted over 9,000 mostly temporary Visitor visas to Ukrainians in Ukraine and hundreds more to Ukrainians elsewhere. Nearly 5,000 of these visa holders have since arrived in Australia.

Almost 5,000 Ukrainian nationals and their families accepted the Australian Government offer of a temporary humanitarian stay. This humanitarian stay, through the subclass 786 visa, and other visa options for Ukrainians after 31 July 2022, will ensure that Ukraine nationals who have had to flee their country due to the Russian invasion have access to work and study for school-aged children, and gain access to Medicare and other relevant support services.

The Government will provide additional funding of $550,000 to Ukrainian and other community organisations to facilitate their provision of support to Ukrainian nationals in Australia. This funding is in addition to $450,000 previously provided to the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations as part of the Government's commitment to supporting the international response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the humanitarian efforts to assist those fleeing the war.
Australia is committed to showing global leadership with regards to the size of our humanitarian intake as one of the world's most generous contributors to international refugee resettlement efforts.

Australia's resettlement program intake has been drawn from a range of nationalities, ethnic and religious groups. The Program operates flexibly to respond to evolving humanitarian situations in the context of record levels of global displacement.

The Department will continue its long-standing partnerships with international organisations, such as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and the International Organization for Migration (IOM), and other resettlement countries to address the challenges of providing effective protection for refugees and displaced persons.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4034 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4042, with 270 signatures, concerning the intake of 20,000 Ukrainian refugees.

The Department of Home Affairs is progressing visa applications from Ukrainian nationals as a priority, particularly for those with a strong, personal connection to Australia. Temporary visa applications to facilitate urgent travel are generally processed within days.

Since 23 February 2022, the Department has granted over 9,500, mostly temporary, visas to Ukrainians in Ukraine and hundreds more to Ukrainians elsewhere. Nearly 4,500 of these visa holders have since arrived in Australia.

Almost 5,000 Ukrainian nationals and their families accepted the Australian Government offer of a temporary humanitarian stay. The Government remains committed to supporting Ukrainians and their family members who are temporarily in Australia as a result of the war in Ukraine. The Temporary Humanitarian visa response was designed to support those initially displaced as a result of the conflict in Ukraine.
Ukrainian nationals who were unable to accept the Government's offer of a Temporary Humanitarian Stay by 31 July 2022, can access other visa options.

Ukrainians and their families who wish to extend their stay in Australia or explore migration options can also continue to access visa pathways including the skilled, family, student and visitor visa programs.
Ukrainians who are unable to access any further visa options or cannot return to Ukraine, may apply for a Bridging E (subclass 050) visa or a Protection (subclass 866) visa.
The Government is committed to ensuring that Ukrainians can continue to reside in the Australian community with access to work, health, education and visa support services.

The Government has provided additional funding of $550,000 to Ukrainian and other community organisations to facilitate their provision of support to Ukrainian nationals in Australia. This funding is in addition to $450,000 previously provided to the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations as part of the Government's commitment to supporting the international response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the humanitarian efforts to assist those fleeing the war.
Australia is committed to showing global leadership with regards to the size of our humanitarian intake as one of the world's most generous contributors to international refugee resettlement efforts.

Australia's resettlement program intake has been drawn from a range of nationalities, ethnic and religious groups. The Program operates flexibly to respond to evolving humanitarian situations in the context of record levels of global displacement.

The Department will continue its long-standing partnerships with international organisations such as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and International Organization for Migration (IOM), and other resettlement countries to address the challenges of providing effective protection for refugees and displaced persons.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4042 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4046, with 16 signatures, concerning special visas for refugees fleeing war in Ukraine.

The Department of Home Affairs is progressing visa applications from Ukrainian citizens as a priority, particularly for those with a strong, personal connection to Australia. Temporary visa applications to facilitate urgent travel are processed generally within days.

Since 23 February 2022, the Department has granted over 9,000, mostly temporary, visas to Ukrainians in Ukraine and hundreds more to Ukrainians elsewhere. Nearly 5,000 of these visa holders have since arrived in Australia.

Almost 5,000 Ukrainian nationals and their families accepted the Australian Government offer of a temporary humanitarian stay. The Government remains committed to supporting Ukrainians and their family members who are temporarily in Australia as a result of the war in Ukraine.

Ukrainians and their families who wish to extend their stay in Australia or explore migration options can continue to access visa pathways including the skilled, family, student and visitor visa programs.
Ukrainians who are unable to access any further visa options or cannot return to Ukraine may apply for a Bridging E (subclass 050) visa (BVE) or a Protection (subclass 866) visa.

The Department encourages Ukrainians to explore what visa options are suitable for them and to seek independent legal advice from a registered migration agent or a lawyer in order to determine the pathway for their individual circumstances.

The Australian Government remains committed to supporting Ukrainians and their family members who are temporarily in Australia as a result of the war in Ukraine. The Government will provide additional funding of $550,000 to Ukrainian and other community organisations to facilitate their provision of support to Ukrainian nationals in Australia. This funding is in addition to $450,000 previously provided to the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations as part of the Australian Government's commitment to supporting the international response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the humanitarian efforts to assist those fleeing the war.
Thank you for bringing EN4046 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Bowel Cancer

span.span: for your correspondence of 26 September 2022 concerning Petition EN4055 for lowering the screening age for the National Bowel Cancer Scr
The Program is a population screening program with a target screening age range

underpinned by the National Health and Medical Research Council's Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Prevention, Early Detection and Management of Colorectal Cancer (Guidelines). While medical evidence acknowledges bowel cancer can occur in individuals y

ounger than 50 and older than 74, the Guidelines are based on best available clinical evidence at a population level and can be found at https://wiki.cancer.org.au/australia/Guidelines:Colorectal_cancer.
These Guidelines are regularly updated, with the pop

ulation screening chapters currently being reviewed to capture the latest published evidence on screening for bowel cancer, including evidence related to the appropriateness of screening age. Modelling underpinning this review

ance of benefits to harms across age ranges, as well as historic Program participation rates and the current rate of 43.5%. The review of the Guidelines is expected to conclude in mid-2023. Any subsequent changes to the Program will require

Through the National Health Reform Agreement, the Government provides funding to state and territory public hospitals to provide a range of services, including colonoscopies. States and territories are responsible for access and deliv

ery of colonoscopy services within their jurisdictions. Data from the 'National Bowel Cancer Screening Program monitoring report 2021' estimates 49 days as the medium time between a positive screen and diagnostic assessment.
People who are riot currently w

ithin the Program's eligible population screening age range that wish to screen, can consult a healthcare provider who may offer screening covered by the Medicare. Alternatively, non-Program screening kits are available for purchase online and at some phar
Thank you for writing on this matter.

p.span: from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence in relation to petition EN4076, presented to the House on 26 September 2022.

I note the petition calls for the criminalisation of wearing a burqa, niqab or any other covering that obscures the face in public spaces. It further calls for fines or imprisonment to be imposed on those who break this law.

Australia is home to a diversity of faiths, united by acceptance, mutual respect and a commitment to democratic traditions. All Australians are free to choose their religion, and are entitled to express and practise their religion and their beliefs, without intimidation and without interference, as long as those practices are within the framework of Australian law. This includes the freedom of people to express their religion through their choice of clothing.

The Australian Government believes that every Australian should be able to live free from discrimination. Just as nobody should be treated unfairly because of their gender, disability, sexuality, age, or race, we also do not believe anyone should experience discrimination because of their religious beliefs. That is why the Government has announced its commitment to the introduction of legislation to prevent faith-based discrimination and vilification.

The Government recognises that law reform is an ongoing process in a healthy society. The Government will continue to reform laws and our legal system to reflect the traditions, values and aspirations of all Australians, and meet the needs of our modem democratic society. The Government considers the current legal framework strikes the appropriate balance and will not be seeking to criminalise the wearing of a burqa or other religious dress.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Member for Cook
Parliamentary Standards
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 referring the above-mentioned petitions to me for response.

On 26 August 2022, the Prime Minister and Attorney-General announced the appointment of the Hoh Virginia Bell AC to conduct an inquiry into the appointment of the Member for Cook, Mr Scott Morrison MP, to multiple ministries.

Ms Bell's inquiry will examine and report on the facts and circumstances surrounding Mr Morrison's appointments and the implications arising from them, as well as the practices and processes which apply to ministerial appointments generally, including recommendations of any procedural or legislative changes.
I have included a copy of the full terms of reference for Ms Bell's inquiry for your reference.
Ms Bell will report to the Prime Minister by Friday 25 November 2022, after which the Government will consider and respond to Ms Bell's report as appropriate.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
Encl.
Inquiry into the appointment of the Hon Scott Morrison MP to administer various portfolios and related matters
Terms of Reference

The Hon Virginia Bell AC has been appointed to conduct an inquiry into the appointment of former Prime Minister the Hon Scott Morrison MP to administer departments other than the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and related matters. The inquiry will:

a) examine and report on the facts and circumstances surrounding the appointment of Mr Morrison to administer the Department of Health, the Department of Finance, the Department of Industry, Science and Energy and Resources, the Department of Home Affairs and the Department of the Treasury, in addition to the Department of the Prime Minister and the Cabinet
b) examine and report on the implications arising from the appointments, including on:
i. the functioning of departments of state, Government Business Enterprises and statutory bodies;
ii. the structure of the Ministry;
iii. the accountability of the executive to the Parliament; and
iv. public confidence in government
c) examine and report on the practices and processes which apply to:
i. the appointment of ministers to administer departments of state under section 64 of the Constitution; and
ii. directions that ministers hold certain offices under section 65 of the Constitution;
including the disclosure of those appointments and directions; and
d) recommend any procedural or legislative changes which would provide greater transparency and accountability.

The inquiry shall have regard to the Solicitor-General's Opinion in the matter of the validity of the appointment of Mr Morrison to administer the Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (SG No. 12 of 2022).
Ms Bell will report to the Prime Minister by Friday, 25 November 2022.
from the Leader of the House, Mr Burke (Petition Nos EN4417, EN4426 and EN4432)
Child Safety
Dear Chair

On 19 December 2022 my office received notification of an outstanding response to a petition sent to the former Government to implement an Australian Design Rule (ADR) requiring warning systems to detect the presence of children left alone in vehicles (EN3670).
I was very sorry to learn of the tragic loss of Rylee Rose Black and the suffering of her family. I understand their wish to prevent tragedies like this from happening in the future.

Road safety is everybody's business and the Australian Government supports the introduction of new technologies that improve the safety of new vehicles. The Government's policy is to harmonise the national vehicle standards with international regulations wherever possible, including United Nations vehicle regulations. This gives Australians access to safer vehicles at the lowest cost.

There is not yet an international standard developed to detect and warn a driver that a child has been left in a vehicle. However, the Government is a major funder of the Australasian New Car Assessment program (ANCAP). ANCAP complements regulation by encouraging both manufacturer fitment and consumer uptake of new vehicle safety systems. This helps bridge the gap for new safety technologies as they become more mature and ready for regulation. Starting in 2023, ANCAP will require their new vehicle rating system to account for Child Presence Detection systems being implemented within vehicles to achieve the highest safety rating.

In the meantime, the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communication and the Arts, is participating in an international working party examining electronic systems that detect and warn of the presence of children left alone in vehicles. Once the international standard has been set, my department will look to include the standard in its forward work program for ADR development.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
