from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Centrelink
Dear Chair

Thank you for the email from the Committee dated 17 February 2022 concerning petition EN3789, which requests that the Australian Government acts to ensure that accommodation costs amount to less than half of the total provided through the JobSeeker Payment or Austudy. The email was directed to the former Minister for Families and Social Services and Minister for Women's Safety, Senator the Hon Anne Ruston, as this matter then fell within her portfolio responsibilities. This matter now falls within my portfolio responsibilities as the Minister for Social Services.

The Australian Government recognises that living on income support payments is challenging, and that it is important that the rate of payments keep up with the cost of living. To address the effects of inflation on the cost of living for those on a payment, income support payments such as JobSeeker Payment are increased each year in March and September in line with the Consumer Price Index.

The Prime Minister has stated that the Government does not have a plan to increase the rate of JobSeeker Payment in the Government's first Budget, noting the importance of acting in a fiscally responsible manner. He further stated that the Government would consider the rates of payments in future Budgets and do what it can to help those in need.

The Government understands that housing is fundamental to the lives and wellbeing of all Australians, and supports programs that allow more people to access housing. Commonwealth Rent Assistance (CRA) is an example of such a program available to those on an income support payment. CRA is a non-taxable income supplement payable with income support payments, Family Tax Benefit Part A, and veterans' service pensions or income support supplements, to eligible individuals and families renting in private rental markets and community housing.

State and territory governments (states) are responsible for the provision of day-to-day housing and homelessness services, using funds distributed federally through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement (NHHA). The NHHA improves accountability, as states are required to have publicly available housing and homelessness strategies, and contribute to improved data collection and reporting. Homelessness strategies must address a range of priority cohorts listed in the NHHA, and outline reforms or initiatives that contribute to a reduction in the incidence of homelessness.

The Government took to the election a commitment to creating a $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund. Each year investment returns from the Housing Australia Future Fund will be transferred to the National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation to pay for constructing, maintaining and repairing social and affordable housing projects.

The Government has also committed to implementing the Help to Buy scheme, which allows eligible buyers to purchase a home with a minimum deposit of 2 per cent, and with an equity contribution from the Government of up to 40 per cent of the value of a new home.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence dated 26 September 2022, regarding the referral of petition EN4007.

I note the concerns expressed by petitioners and subsequent request to extend Commonwealth Rent Assistance (CRA) payments, or equivalent "accommodation assistance" to homeowners on income support payments. The Australian Government understands access to secure and affordable housing has significant social, economic and personal benefits.

CRA is an important component of the income support and family payment systems. It contributes to the improvement of housing affordability and complements broader income support objectives by assisting individuals and families with the additional costs associated with renting in the private market and in community housing.

In order to receive CRA, a person must pay or be liable to pay eligible rent above a minimum level, called the rent threshold. CRA is then calculated at 75 cents for each dollar above the rent threshold up to a maximum rate. The amount of CRA people are eligible for is also dependent on their family situation (single, couple, how many children, if any, and for single people whether they are sharing accommodation).
The Australian Government expects to spend around $5.1 billion on CRA in 2022-23, to assist around 1.4 million eligible individuals and families with the cost of their rent.

Security of tenure is one of the significant benefits of owning a home, and there are concessions in the social security system for homeowners; for example, the value of a person's principal home is not taken into account in working out the amount of pension or benefit they can receive. If the value of a person's home was treated in the same way as other assets, such as bank accounts or shares, many homeowners would receive far less in pensions or benefits than is currently the case, and many would receive no payment.

The Government is also working to help Australian households more easily access safe and affordable housing through a number of strategic initiatives to improve housing supply and affordability in the medium and long term, including:
the National Housing Accord;
the Housing Australia Future Fund;
the establishment of the National Housing Supply and Affordability Council; and
the creation of a National Housing and Homelessness Plan.

Combined, these policies will support access to housing, align the efforts of the Commonwealth and state and territory governments to deliver better housing outcomes, and increase housing supply and affordability for renters and buyers across Australia.
I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Parliamentary Standards
Dear Ms Templeman

I am writing in response to your correspondence of 27 September 2022 addressed to Senator the Hon Don Farrell, Special Minister of State, regarding Petition EN4045 to introduce a Parliamentary Accountability, Transparency and Disclosures Act.

Accountability and transparency are vital to the maintenance of public trust in our institutions and the health of democratic government. They are particularly important for public officials, whose behaviour and interests must be subjected to public scrutiny. Fortunately, there are already a number of measures in place to ensure that accountability and transparency are maintained. These include the requirements for registration of Members' and Senators' interests and the Code of Conduct for Ministers, both of which are outlined below.

The Government recognises, however, that despite these existing measures, the risk of misconduct and corruption by public officials is always very real. That is why the Government is currently progressing a number of initiatives, aimed at tackling corruption and restoring trust and integrity to federal politics.

Notably, the Government recently delivered on one of its key election commitments by legislating for a powerful, transparent and independent National Anti-Corruption Commission. The Commission is due to commence its work in mid-2023. The Commission will have broad jurisdiction to investigate serious or systemic corrupt conduct across the Commonwealth public sector, including by ministers, parliamentarians and their staff.

The Government is also committed to improving the standard of behaviour in Parliamentary Workplaces more broadly. We are currently working across the Parliament to implement all 28 recommendations of the Set the Standard: Report on the Independent Review into Commonwealth Parliamentary Workplaces (the Set the Standard Report). Implementation is a shared responsibility and led by a multi-party Parliamentary Leadership Taskforce. The Taskforce publishes progress on implementing the Report's recommendations on its website
.(https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Leadership_Taskforce).

On 29 November 2022, the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Standards tabled its report on codes of conduct for parliamentarians, their staff and Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces. The Government is considering that Report in conjunction with the establishment of the Independent Parliamentary Standards Commission, which the Set the Standard Report recommended should enforce the codes of conduct.

span.span: Register of Members' and Senators' Interests

p.span: A register of interests is maintained for both Members and Senators. The purpose of these registers is to place on the public record Members' and Senators' interests which may conflict, or may be seen to conflict, with their public duty. Matters which Members and Senators are required to register are set out in various resolutions and standing orders. Registration of Members' interests is supervised by the Standing Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests, whereas registration of Senators' interests is supervised by the Senate Standing Committees of Senators' Interests.
Requirements for Registration

Within 28 days of making an oath or affirmation, each Member and Senator is required to provide to the Registrar of Members' or Senators' Interests a statement of the Member's or Senator's registrable interests. The registrable interests, of which the Member or Senator is aware, of the Member's or Senator's spouse or partner and any children wholly or mainly dependent on the Member or Senator for support must also be included in the statement. The statement is to include:
in the case of new Members and Senators, interests held at the date of the Member's or Senator's election
in the case of re-elected Members and Senators of the immediately preceding Parliament, interests held at the date of dissolution of that Parliament
changes in interests between these dates and the date of the statement.
Members and Senators who knowingly fail to adhere to these requirements or provide false or misleading information shall be guilty of contempt of their respective chamber.

The Code of Conduct for Ministers sets out expectations for the conduct and behaviour of Ministers. The Code is underpinned by key principles that Ministers must act with due regard for integrity, fairness, accountability, responsibility and the public interest.

Ministers are expected to demonstrate they are complying with the high standards of conduct and, in doing so, living up to the expectations of the Australian public. Ministers, and their staff, are also now required to undertake mandatory training to ensure everyone contributes to creating safe and respectful workplaces.

Ministers are required to register their private interests publicly on the parliamentary Register of Members' or Senators' Interests. Ministers are also required to provide private interests declarations directly to the Prime Minister, and report any potential conflicts to the Cabinet Secretary.
I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Natural Disasters
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4048 on superannuation contributions for Members of Parliament.

Remuneration provided to Members of Parliament is based on determinations made by tribunal under the Parliamentary Business Resources Act 2017. The superannuation guarantee (SG) forms part of the total remuneration package. Newly elected Parliamentarians receive an SG rate of15.4 per cent in line with the Parliamentary Superannuation Act 2004. This higher rate than the legislated SG is designed to recognise that these employer contributions are replacing a defined benefit pension scheme. It does not represent an extra cost to the Commonwealth than if this amount was paid as ordinary salary.

All Australians are able to make additional voluntary contributions to their superannuation. Currently, individuals can make additional concessional (before tax) contributions to superannuation up to an annual cap of $27,500 and non-concessional (after tax) contributions up to the annual cap of$110,000 for those with superannuation balances under $1.7 million. These caps are indexed in line with wages growth, and were most recently increased on 1 July 2021 by 10 per cent. In addition, since 1 July 2019 individuals can carry forward any unused proportion of the $27,500 concessional contributions cap for up to five years, if they have a superannuation balance of less than $500,000.

More broadly, the Government is committed to ensuring that superannuation works for all Australians in their retirement and has made a number of policy commitments in recent months. These commitments include addressing the problem of unpaid superannuation and ensuring that the Superannuation Guarantee continues to increase to 12 per cent as legislated.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022, enclosing Petition EN4071, with 33 signatures, advocating the banning of representatives and persons associated with the following Ukrainian groups: National Militia, Azov Movement, The Right Sector Movement, Aidar Battalion, Donbass Battalion, and Dnepr Battalion.

Under the Counter-Terrorism (Temporary Exclusion Orders) Act 2019 (Temporary Exclusion Orders), as the Minister for Home Affairs, I may make an order that prevents a person from entering Australia for a specified period of up to two years. An order cannot be made unless certain criteria is met, and such an order can be revoked.

In making a decision to either make a Temporary Exclusion Order or to cancel or refuse to grant a visa on character grounds, I consider the advice of Australian security law enforcement agencies, in addition to Australia's existing legislative and international obligations.

In addition, under section 501 of the Migration Act 1958, I may refuse to grant or cancel a visa to a person if I am not satisfied that the person passes the character test and I am satisfied that the refusal or cancellation is in the national interest. The character test is broadly concerned with a person's criminal record, their association with persons suspected of engaging in criminal conduct, and the risk of particular types of future conduct.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4071 to my attention.
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Fuel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4074 to suspend fuel taxes for 12 months.

In the 2022 23 March Budget the previous Government halved the fuel excise rate for a period of six months from 30 March 2022 to 11:59 pm on 28 September 2022. This change has now ended and the excise rates have reverted to previous rates, including indexation that would have occurred on those rates during the six-month period.

The Government recognises that the cost of fuel is putting family and business budgets under significant pressure and driving up the price of essentials like groceries. Whilst the Government appreciates this pressure, given the state of the Commonwealth budget, the Government was not in a position to extend this measure beyond the legislated end date.

I was pleased to see that fuel companies appeared to be gradually adjusting their prices in the weeks after 28 September. That said, it remains critical that fuel companies promptly pass on any reductions in international oil prices and do not take advantage of the end of the excise reduction to penalise consumers. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is responsible for monitoring fuel prices and plays a critical role in ensuring that market participants do not take advantage of consumers. I previously wrote to the Chair of the ACCC, Ms Gina Cass-Gottlieb, instructing the Commission to step up its surveillance of fuel markets following the reintroduction of the full excise rate. As the independent regulator investigates concerns about anti-competitive conduct and misleading representations in fuel markets and takes appropriate action. The ACCC is also engaging with major retailers and wholesalers to ensure that they do not mislead Australian consumers about the rationale for any price rises.

The level of competition between fuel retailers is also very important. To help drive competition, the ACCC recommends that consumers take advantage of fuel price websites and mobile applications that allow them to select the best time to purchase fuel, as well as the cheapest location.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Fuel

Workplace Relations
Dear Ms Templeman
I refer to your correspondence of 27 September 2022, regarding the petition for surveys of contracted government employees (petition EN4089).

As this petition seeks the implementation of contractor surveys across Government, this becomes a policy matter for consideration. Ownership of all policy matters relating to procurement and contracting arrangements are determined by the Department of Finance.

from the Minister for Government Services, Mr Shorten
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4091, with 40 signatures, concerning contingent visas to 60 persecuted Chinese Christians from deportation.

The Australian Government is committed to compassionate and flexible Humanitarian and Settlement Programs that meet Australia's international protection obligations and position Australia as a global leader in international resettlement efforts.

Since the end of World War II, Australia has successfully settled more than 930,000 refugees and others in humanitarian need, recognising the valuable contribution that refugees provide to Australian society, culture and prosperity.
Australia's Humanitarian Program aims to:
meet Australia's international protection obligations, so that Australia is an exemplar in our region and beyond;
provide permanent resettlement to those most in need, who are in desperate situations, including in refugee camps and protracted refugee situations;

use resettlement strategically to help stabilise refugee populations, reduce the prospect of irregular movement from source countries and countries of first asylum, and support broader international protection;
be flexible and responsive to changing global resettlement needs and emerging
humanitarian situations to ensure Australia's approach remains comprehensive and high-quality; and
reunite refugees and people who are in refugee-like situations overseas with their family in Australia.

The world is experiencing its greatest humanitarian need since World War II, with the largest number of displaced persons since that time. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) estimated that in 2023 there will be more than 21.3 million refugees globally, of which 2.003 million persons will be in need of resettlement. The Government is committed to a Humanitarian Program that can respond to international humanitarian crises as they arise, and to provide appropriate support for the travel and resettlement of refugees and others requiring Australia's protection.

To ensure Australia continues to play its part, the Government will work closely with UNHCR, the community, and stakeholders as we deliver Australia's Humanitarian Program intake. Australia's Humanitarian Program is designed primarily to assist people who have left their home country because of persecution or severe human rights abuses, and who have no options for return or for resettlement in another country. The Program intake is drawn from a range of nationalities, ethnic and religious groups, reflecting global displacement arising from conflict and persecution.

The Government is committed to a non-discriminatory approach to this intake and to prioritising those caseloads most in need of global resettlement, in line with guidance and referrals from UNHCR. Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. Each application is considered on its individual merit using current and comprehensive information on circumstances in the relevant country.

Australia has and continues to welcome humanitarian entrants from a broad range of religious backgrounds. While some people as part of their refugee claims may disclose their religion, it is not a requirement that applicants do so on their application form. It remains open to members of a religious minority, like any other person facing persecution or substantial discrimination in their home country, to lodge an application under the Program.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4091 to my attention.
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Standards Australia
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring a copy of the petition (Petition Ministerial Referral EN4101) to me and bringing this matter to my attention.

Standards Australia is Australia's national standards body, with responsibility for developing and distributing Australian Standards. It is a non-government, not-for-profit company limited by guarantee, governed by a board of directors and its members represent Australia's technical and commercial infrastructure, industry, unions, academia and government. Standards Australia develop standards based on three internationally recognised principles, including openness and transparency, consensus and balance of representation.

As noted in the petition, where a standard is referenced in federal, state and/or territory regulation, businesses are required to purchase the relevant standard(s), on a user pays basis, in order to ensure they operate in compliance with the law. This model compensates Standards Australia for the cost of developing, maintaining and distributing its total catalogue of standards.

The revenue from the distribution of standards is used by Standards Australia to support the committees and processes that bring relevant experts together. Charging for standards is not unique to Australia and is common throughout developed economies. We acknowledge that Australian Industry also make a significant investment in the standards development process, through voluntary contributions of time and expertise.

While the Albanese Government maintains a keen interest in ensuring that Australian standards are developed in a way that delivers a net benefit to the Australian community as a whole, the Government cannot direct Standards Australia on its distribution model or prices.

The Commonwealth continues to raise with Standards Australia the feedback from stakeholders on the cost and access to Australian Standards. Standards Australia are well aware of industry's concerns and has made five commitments to the Commonwealth related to improved standards accessibility, as outlined in the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Standards Australia (section 8.32):
1. Improve the competition in the distribution of standards by supporting multiple channels for distribution;
2. Offer partnership options with Standards Australia to facilitate forms of public access;
3. Develop new innovative channels for accessing standards;
4. Provide greater flexibility in pricing structures; and
5. Provide public access to standards for non-commercial use.

Both Australian and international standards can be purchased via Standards Australia and its distributors (TechStreet and SAI Global). Between 2003 and 2019, Standards were distributed in Australia exclusively by SAI Global, a company initially listed on the ASX and then owned by Baring Asia Limited, a private equity organisation. In 2019, Standards Australia appointed Techstreet as their second distributor. In 2021, Standards Australia launched their own channel to market through the Standards Australia Store. The Commonwealth has welcomed Standard Australia's efforts to move towards multiple channels for distribution, as a means of ensuring increased competition in the distribution of standards. I understand from Standards Australia that they continue to assess other potential distributors under their Distribution and Licensing Policy Framework.

Standards Australia recently released Small Business Sets to combine commonly referenced documents across select industries into a single package, with a variety of subscription terms. Standards Australia have advised that they are working with other third-party organisations to develop further innovations in the distribution of standards, including using mobile apps, and are exploring different pricing models. Standards Australia has committed to providing free access to its content for personal, domestic and household use by December 2023.

I am assured by Standards Australia that they remain committed to improving standards accessibility, including through digital content, as outlined in the MoU, which will ensure that their products meet the expectations of many more users. I wish to emphasise that the Government continues to advocate for the interests of Australian industry and engage closely with Standards Australia on the matter of cost and access to Australian standards.
Thank you again for bringing the concerns raised in this petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Industry and Science, Mr Husic

subdebateinfo.title: Pensions and Benefits: Veterans and Emergency Services Personnel

p.span: Pensions and Benefits: Veterans and Emergency Services Personnel
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon Matt Keogh MP, regarding petition EN4281. Your email was referred to me as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government appreciates the important economic and social contribution senior Australians make to our community and is keen to ensure that pensioners' living standards are safeguarded by the Age Pension.

Australians are living longer than before and the Government is committed to ensuring the Age Pension is sustainable and future demand can be met. When the Age Pension was introduced in 1909, the average male life expectancy at birth was 55; it is now over 80. Consistent with legislation passed in 2009, the Age Pension qualification age has been increasing by 6 months every 2 years until it reaches 67 years on 1 July 2023. It is currently 66.5 years. To receive the Age Pension, a person must also satisfy the residence requirements and have income and assets below certain limits.

If a person below Age Pension qualification age is unable to work, they may be eligible for an alternative social security payment. For example, they may qualify for payments such as Disability Support Pension or JobSeeker Payment, subject to eligibility criteria. Alternatively, people with qualifying service may be able to receive the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) Service Pension.

The DVA Service Pension, payable under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, is an income support payment that provides a regular income for veterans with limited means. Service Pension can be paid to eligible veterans on the grounds of age or invalidity, and to eligible partners, widows and widowers. The veteran must have qualifying service to be eligible for Service Pension and partners must be linked to a veteran with qualifying service to be eligible. Australian, Allied and Commonwealth veterans may have qualifying service if they have served:
in operations against the enemy;
in an operational area (specified location) during certain time periods;
at a time when they incurred danger from hostile forces of the enemy; and/or
were on a deployment which the Minister for Defence has declared to be warlike service.

Age Service Pension is similar in many ways to the Services Australia (Centrelink) Age Pension, and is payable at age 60, as opposed to Age Pension qualification age, to take into account the impacts of service on a veteran's ability to keep working. Similar to the Age Pension, the amount of Service Pension a person receives depends on their income and assets, referred to as the means test.
Thank you again for writing.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

subdebateinfo.title: Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia

p.span: Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence dated 9 November 2022 to the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, Prime Minister, regarding a petition for the appointment of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales as the Governor-General of Australia (ref: EN4478). The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

The Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia is appointed by His Majesty The King on the advice and recommendation of the Prime Minister and under the provisions of the Letters Patent relating to the office. Individuals appointed to the role have generally excelled in their profession and are held in the highest regard by their peers and broader community.

The Governor-General holds office at His Majesty's pleasure; however, the term is usually understood to be five years. His Excellency General the Honourable David Hurley AC DSC (Retd) was sworn in as Australia's 27th Governor-General on 1 July 2019.
The Prime Minister will consider the appointment of the next Governor-General in due course. I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 10 November 2022, on behalf of the Petitions Committee reference number EN4483, regarding a referendum on becoming a Republic.
The Albanese Labor Government believes that our nation's Constitution is a living document which should be amended to reflect contemporary Australia and to embody Australian values.

Over twenty years have passed since the Australian people were consulted about our Constitution. While there's been no referendum since 1999, there's been no successful referendum since 1977. Indeed, it's been the longest period we have gone without the government consulting Australians about updating Constitution.

The Albanese Government's priority for Constitutional reform remains recognition of First Nations peoples in the Australian Constitution, including an enshrined Voice to Parliament, as outlined in the Uluru Statement from the Heart.

The Government supports and will work towards establishing an Australian Republic with an Australian head of state. Each and every Australian, no matter their background, birthplace, gender or religion should be able to aspire to be our nation's head of state.

The Albanese Government will continue to consult the Australian people, including on potential models for an Australian Republic. While I have been appointed Assistant Minister for the Republic to advance the debate on an Australian head of state, Constitutional recognition and a Voice to Parliament for First Nations people remain the Government's Constitutional reform priority.
Thank you for bringing petition EN4483 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for the Republic, Mr Thistlethwaite
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding the reintroduction of mandatory COVID-19 isolation.
I acknowledge the COVID-19 pandemic has and continues to be a challenging time for many Australians, and I recognise the concerns raised by the petitioners.

The Australian Government response to the COVID-19 pandemic continues to be informed by leading medical and public health experts, including the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation. Comprised of all state and territory Chief Health Officers and chaired by the Australian Chief Medical Officer, the AHPPC works with state and territory health departments to develop and adopt national health protection policies, guidelines, standards and seek alignment of plans.

The National Cabinet decision to remove mandatory isolation requirements, effective 14 October 2022, is considered a proportionate approach in the Australian context of readily available access to treatments and vaccines, and high underlying population immunity.

I stress that the removal of mandatory isolation requirements does not diminish the importance of protective behaviours, including staying at home and avoiding high-risk settings while sick, keeping up to date with recommended vaccinations and mask use in crowded public indoor settings. All states and territories continue to strongly recommend COVID-19 cases stay at home until their symptoms have resolved.
More information about COVID-safe behaviours can be found at www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/protect-yourself-and-others.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Your sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler (Petition No. EN4520)
Veterinary Medicines
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, with regards to a petition presented in the House requesting that the House establish a Pets Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (Pets PBS) and that veterinarians be given access. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, as the matter you have raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
While understanding the benefits that companion animals can provide to many pensioners, and to the wider Australian public, at this time the government will not contemplate a Pets PBS.

The PBS forms part of the Australian Government's broader National Medicines Policy which aims to meet medication related service needs, to achieve optimal health outcomes and economic objectives. Costs of medicines are only a component of this consideration, and not all human medicines used in Australia are covered by the PBS. The government committed $13.8 billion to the PBS in 2020-21 financial year. The establishment of a PBS for animals, either companion animals or broader agriculture, would require substantial government funding and represent a significant shift in government priorities.

Australia has a regulatory scheme for veterinary medicines that assesses the safety and efficacy (including animal safety) of veterinary medicines. The independent statutory regulator, the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA), maintains a public database of Australian registered products. The effectiveness and safety of products registered in Australia will be the same, independent of the supply means, online or bricks and mortar establishments. Users can check on veterinary products, purchased online or in a bricks and mortar establishment, are registered by the APVMA, by searching portal.apvma.gov.au/pubcris.
Thank you for providing me the opportunity to respond to this petition.
I have copied this letter to the Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP and to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt (Petition No. EN4531)
COVID-19: Vaccine
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4554 asking the House of Representatives to remove COVID-19 mRNA vaccines from market, to not allow the provisional approval of COVID-19 vaccines or medicines, and to review indemnity arrangements for COVID-19 vaccine sponsors.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), part of the Department of Health and Aged Care, has comprehensively evaluated each of the provisionally registered COVID-19 vaccines (including the mRNA vaccines sponsored by Pfizer and Moderna) to ensure that they meet Australia's high standards of safety, quality, and efficacy. This formal regulatory approval means that the vaccines can be lawfully supplied in Australia.

Due to the urgent nature of the COVID-19 pandemic, the TGA expedited the review of COVID-19 vaccines via the provisional approval pathway, which existed prior to the pandemic. This pathway enables earlier access to promising new medicines while data on longer term efficacy and safety are still being gathered. Use of the provisional pathway is based on an assessment that the benefit of early availability of the medicine outweighs the risks inherent in the fact that additional data are still required.

The TGA's evaluation process is robust. A team of technical and clinical experts at the TGA carefully evaluate the data submitted by the sponsor, to ensure that strict safety, quality, and efficacy thresholds are met.

Advice is also sought from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, a Ministerially appointed independent committee of external experts, before a regulatory decision is made under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.A vaccine is only provisionally registered by the TGA if this rigorous process is completed, and the benefits of the vaccine are much greater than any potential risks.

Even though the decision to provisionally approve these vaccines was based on short-term efficacy and safety data, the data submitted for the COVID-19 vaccines clearly supported a positive benefit-risk ratio in the prevailing context of the pandemic. Waiting for data to establish the duration of protection would have significantly delayed the availability of these vaccines.

The TGA has published a range of regulatory documents relating to the provisional registration of each COVID-19 vaccine. These include the Australian Public Assessment Report, the Product Information and the Consumer Medicine Information documents, which are available at www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines.

As part of the provisional registration, sponsors are required to continue to submit longer-term evidence to the TGA. These studies are continuing to gather data on longer-term safety and effectiveness to complement post-market monitoring and spontaneous adverse event data and are due for completion by mid-2024.

The TGA also has a well-established and effective system in place to detect and investigate potential new safety issues relating to vaccines. Many of these processes have been enhanced dramatically for COVID-19 vaccines, making this the most intense safety monitoring of therapeutic goods ever conducted in Australia.

By way of transparency, the TGA publishes fortnightly COVID-19 vaccine safety updates at www.tga.gov.au/periodic/covid-19-vaccine-safety-report. In addition to coordinated safety monitoring efforts between the Commonwealth and states and territories, vaccine sponsors are also required by law to continue to monitor the safety of their products.

The TGA works closely with other regulators around the world to continually analyse the latest evidence from clinical trials and follow-up studies. There are also enormous amounts of real-world safety data covering hundreds of millions of people worldwide.

Reassuringly, these data in addition to numerous peer-reviewed published studies in top-tier medical journals continue to support the safe and effective use of COVID-19 vaccines. It is the consensus view of international regulators that the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination continue to far outweigh the rare risks.

As COVID-19 transmission continues, it is expected that the total number of COVID-19 infections among fully vaccinated people, including those that experience severe illness (i.e. hospitalisation, Intensive Care Unit admission or death), will rise. This does not mean the vaccines are not working. As seen globally and in Australia, people who are fully vaccinated are far less likely to develop severe disease than those who are not vaccinated.

Based on data in the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS), in jurisdictions with high completeness of vaccination status among COVID-19 associated deaths, the proportion of cases who have died is higher among non-vaccinated cases than fully vaccinated cases. This emphasises the continued importance of vaccination for preventing severe illness.

In cases with an illness onset between 15 December 2021 and 4 September 2022, the proportion of people who have died is more than 22 times as high in unvaccinated compared to fully vaccinated people aged 12-49 years, over 32 times as high in people aged 50 to 69 years and over 14 times as high in people aged 70 and over (Table 1, below).

ern Territory, South Australia, Queensland, and Western Australia, 15 December 2021 to 4 September 2022A^*

The details of APAs with pharmaceutical companies for the purchase of COVID-19 vaccines are commercial-in-confidence.

Australians have embraced COVID-19 vaccination with over 64 million doses given around the country. I encourage all Australians to keep up to date with their vaccinations, in· accordance with official recommendations, to ensure the best protection against COVID-19. The safety of the Australian population has always and will continue to be the Government's highest priority.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Taxation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4555 on Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to review the tax-free threshold in line with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) every year. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

While the Government notes the concern raised in the petition, it does not support automatically indexing the tax-free threshold. Indexation of any income tax thresholds would reduce the fiscal flexibility for future governments to respond to fluctuations in the economic cycle.

Further, regular increases to the tax-free threshold would also not deliver targeted assistance to individuals based on their circumstances, as the tax-free threshold applies to all Australian taxpayers. Consequently, raising the tax-free threshold would be costly and limit the funds available for the Government to provide targeted assistance to low-income earners.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
Census

span.span: your correspondence concerning Petition EN4557, on the inclusion of LGBT
IA+ topics in the Census of Population and Housing (the Census).
will shortly begin reviewing the topics and questions that will be collected
in the 2026 Census of Population and Housing. The details of Petition EN4557 will automatically feed into this review.
The ABS will also be undertaking public consultation on the Census topics in early 2023. Whilst the signatories of Petition EN4557 do no

t need to put forward a separate submission, they can provide more information to support their request if they choose. The signatories can also subscribe to receive updates regarding the topic review process at www.subscribe.abs.
its review, the ABS will consider a range of factors, including the policy need for the data and whether there would be any sensitivities in asking particular questions.
The ABS will let the public know the outcome of this review. Recommendations for the t
opics to be collected in the 2026
Census will then be submitted for a decision by the Australian Government.
I have copied this letter to the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP, Treasurer. I trust this information will be of assistance.

p.span: from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
Public Transport
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 28 November 2022 regarding petition EN4560 which suggests seatbelts as standard fitment in all buses.

Bus passenger fatalities are relatively low in Australia. In 2020 for example (the most recent year with complete statistics), one bus occupant lost their life in a road crash. Statistics on heavy vehicle related road trauma can be found at: www.bitre.gov.au/publications/ongoing/road-trauma-involving-heavy-vehicles.

The requirements for seatbelts are set out in the national vehicle standards, administered under the Road Vehicle Standards Act 2018. The national vehicle standards are commonly known as the Australian Design Rules (ADRs) and the requirements for seatbelts are included in ADR 68/00.

Acknowledging the general safety of bus transportation and in recognition of the different operational needs for buses throughout Australia, the ADR requires seatbelts for each seat in buses that do not allow standing passengers (for example coaches for long distance travel), while allowing route-service buses (such as public transport and school buses) to be supplied to the market without seatbelts. I would note that mandating the use of seatbelts in route-service buses, where several dozen people may use the same seatbelt in a single day, could introduce new risks for those passengers.

The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts, which manages the ADR framework, meets regularly with state and territory in-service regulators to discuss Australian vehicle standards. At present, that group is focused on higher priority vehicle safety technologies that will have a greater impact on reducing road trauma, however, I have forwarded the petition on to my department for their consideration in any future review of the seatbelt ADR.
Thank you for bringing the petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 on behalf of Petition EN4566 signees regarding Medicare bulk billing.

I note the Petition signees' request that the Australian Government prioritise policies that support bulk billing. The Department of Health and Aged Care is working closely with state and territory governments, Primary Health Networks (PHNs), and the health industry to ensure that appropriate protocols are in place to work towards a health system that meets the needs of Australians.
The Government has committed to broader reform in primary care, and to strengthen Medicare, through a commitment of $1 billion which will directly benefit GPs and their patients. This includes:
$750 million to deliver investments in primary care reform identified by the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce (Taskforce)
$135 million to establish 50 Medicare Urgent Care Clinics across Australia to ease pressures on emergency departments

$220 million to deliver the Strengthening Medicare GP Grants Program which provides grants to GP practices to make improvements, allowing for the provision of better care and attending to more patients.

I chaired the Taskforce, bringing together Australia's health policy leaders, including the Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine, the Consumers Health Forum of Australia, and the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation. Details of the Taskforce including communiques can be found at www.health.gov.au/committees-and-groups/strengthening-medicare-taskforce.

The Taskforce held its sixth and final meeting on Tuesday, 13 December 2022. At this meeting the Taskforce discussed recommendations on the future of primary care in Australia. A final report outlining the priorities for investment under the $750 million Strengthening Medicare Fund will be provided to Government by the end of 2022 for consideration.

While the Government is responsible for setting Medicare fees and rebates, GPs operate their practices as private businesses and are free to determine whether they bulk bill some or all of their patients, or charge a co-payment. Doctors are encouraged to consider the personal circumstances of their patients when determining the fees they charge. To support GPs who bulk bill their patients, the Government provides a bulk billing incentive for bulk billed services for patients with a Commonwealth Concession Card and children under 16 years of age. More information about the bulk billing incentives is available on the department's website at www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/rural-bulk-billing-incentives.

Where possible, patients are encouraged to select an appropriate health provider based on their health care and financial needs. Information about medical practices offering bulk billed services can be found using the 'service finder' on the healthdirect website at www.healthdirect.gov.au.

The Government also recognises that unforeseen out-of-pocket expenses can add to the distress of those who suffer serious or unexpected illnesses and provides assistance to patients who incur high out-of-pocket medical expenses through both the Original Medicare Safety Net and the Extended Medicare Safety Net (EMSN). The EMSN provides benefits of up to 80% of out-of-pocket costs for eligible out-of-hospital services once an annual threshold of out-of-pocket expenses is reached. The current EMSN threshold for Commonwealth Concession Card holders and Family Tax Benefit Part A participants in 2022 is $717.90 and the general public threshold is $2,249.80. Thresholds are indexed annually on 1 January in line with the Consumer Price Index. Both safety nets are calendar year programs, renewing on 1 January each year. More information is available at www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/medicare-safety-nets.

The Government also funds PHNs to commission health services to ensure people who are not able to access Medicare-subsidised services due to financial hardship, can still receive health care. While patient co-contributions can be charged, PHNs consider the specific circumstances of client populations and provide low or no cost services where appropriate. Patients may find it useful if their GP contacts the local PHN to discuss the health and support services available. More information is available at www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/phn.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Stuttering and Other Fluency Disorders
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding petition EN4568 to establish a National Stuttering Awareness Week that was presented to the House of Representatives.

I appreciate the efforts made to increase awareness of the issues affecting people who stutter. The work that is being done is important to enhancing people's quality of life and improving their physical and mental wellbeing.

You may be aware that Speech Pathology Australia (SPA) is the primary professional association for speech pathologists and has a role in raising awareness of speech conditions such as stuttering. I believe that SPA would be the organisation best suited to increasing the profile of National Stuttering Awareness Week across Australia, and I encourage you to reach out to them to discuss how best to promote it. They can be contacted at office@speechpathologyaustralia.org.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondences of 27 September 2022 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition PN0536 with 221 signatures, concerning individuals in immigration detention in Australia and under regional processing arrangements. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government is committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs, but remains concerned that people smugglers are poised to prey on and exploit potential irregular immigrants throughout our region for their own financial gain. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining regional processing and the policy that people who attempt to travel to Australia irregularly by boat will not settle here.

As at 21 November 2022, three transitory persons brought to Australia for a temporary purpose to receive medical treatment remain in held detention. The circumstances of these individuals is reviewed regularly. The Government is committed to pursuing alternatives to detention and has released many individuals from detention since May 2022 who are assessed as posing a low risk to the Australian community.

The Government is committed to finding durable migration outcomes for people under regional processing arrangements, including individuals in Nauru and Australia. We continue to support the implementation of third country resettlement arrangements with the United States and New Zealand; over 1,070 people having already been resettled in the United States and a sizeable number are pursuing resettlement in New Zealand. The Government is aware of transitory persons engaged in the Canadian Private Sponsorship of Refugees program, and is providing logistical assistance to Canada.

Individuals are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to achieve permanent migration outcomes and start the next phase of their lives.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0536 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Human Rights: Iran
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your emails regarding petitions EN4511, EN4512, EN4524, EN4525, EN4533, EN4535, EN4559 and EN4503 requesting Australia take action against the Iranian Government.

Iran's human rights record has been a longstanding and serious concern for Australia. Since September 2022, we have been deeply alarmed by the deadly and disproportionate use of force against protesters in Iran, following the tragic death of Ms Mahsa 'Jina' Amini. Hundreds of people have been killed and many more injured, including dozens of children, as a result of heavy-handed measures by Iranian authorities.

The Australian Government is taking decisive action to increase pressure on Iran over its egregious human rights abuses. We have repeatedly raised our concerns with Iran in Canberra, Tehran, and multilateral forums. The Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, has publicly condemned the crackdown by Iranian authorities, called on Iran to respect the rights of peaceful protesters, and expressed support for Iranian women and girls. As Foreign Minister, I have made numerous public statements, as have other senior Ministers including the Attorney-General and the Minister for Women.

On 10 December 2022, I announced human rights sanctions on six Iranian individuals, the Morality Police, and the Basij Resistance Force. I also announced sanctions on three Iranian individuals and one business involved in the supply of drones to Russia for use against Ukraine. These sanctions are in addition to Australia's existing UN and autonomous sanctions on Iran, under which we have imposed targeted sanctions on the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps since 2012. Australia keeps its sanctions regime under regular review and continues to monitor developments in Iran closely.

I have been disturbed by Iran's recent execution of protesters. On 16 December 2022, I released a joint statement with Canadian Foreign Minister Joly and New Zealand Foreign Minister Mahuta calling on Iran to immediately establish a moratorium to halt all executions. The Attorney-General and I have both made additional public statements, and will continue to speak out. The Australian Government opposes the death penalty in all circumstances for all people.

The Australian Government, through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, has called in the Charge d'Affaires of the Iranian Embassy in Canberra on multiple occasions since the protests began to raise concerns regarding the Iranian authorities' heavy-handed crackdown and media reports alleging intimidation of protesters in Australia. We have also spoken to the Charge to raise our deep concerns at the execution of protesters in Iran as well as media reports alleging intimidation of protesters in Australia.

On 14 December 2022 Australia cosponsored the resolution to remove Iran from the UN's Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) and delivered a national statement condemning Iran's persecution of women and girls. In addition, Australia cosponsored and provided crucial advocacy in support of the UN Human Rights Council Special Session resolution on human rights in Iran calling for the establishment of an independent Fact-Finding Mission into Iran's human rights violations.

The Australian Government has also made our views clear through a number of other multilateral statements, including a statement to the UN General Assembly Third Committee Interactive Dialogue with the Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights in Iran on 26 October 2022. On 30 September 2022 we signed on to a joint statement at the 51st Session of the UN Human Rights Council, denouncing the excessive use of force by the Iranian authorities.

Australia stands with Iranian women and girls in their struggle for equality and empowerment, and we call on Iran to cease its oppression of women. We are committed to promoting gender equality, women's empowerment, and ending violence against women and girls worldwide.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I am pleased to report the high number of ministerial responses received, and, on behalf of the committee, I would like to thank the ministers responsible. Every one of these petitions represents an issue which is important to a group of Australians and which deserves a considered and thoughtful response.

Today I table a response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs that responds to several petitions that were signed by, in total, 55,232 petitioners. These petitions varied in their wording but were united in their request for Australia to take action against the Iranian government for its human rights abuses. The response from the minister setting out the government's actions should assure these petitioners that this matter is being taken seriously and that Australians are united in their opposition to oppression, particularly of women and girls.
I look forward to updating the House further on the work of the Petitions Committee.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Electoral Legislation Amendment (Lowering the Voting Age) Bill 2023

p.span: Electoral Legislation Amendment (Lowering the Voting Age) Bill 2023
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Bates.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr BATES (Brisbane) (10:04): I move:
That the bill be now read a second time.

Today I rise to introduce the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Lowering the Voting Age) Bill 2023, a bill to lower the voting age in Australia to 16. Around the world, young people are making their voices heard on the issues that matter to them most. Across the globe, we are seeing the ever-increasing politicisation of young people driven by government inaction, and Australia is no stranger to this. Young people are more engaged in politics than ever before and are already taking actions outside of the political system to shape the future that they will inherit. These actions happen because young people want to drive change on the crises that are facing our society: climate change, access to health care, housing affordability and racial justice. These are issues that young people are passionate about because they are the ones who stand to lose the most from government inaction.

To be growing up in a time of rising rates of inequality and poverty as well as climate change and to see the top one per cent become wealthier and wealthier at the expense of working and middle-class families is more than enough to mobilise young people to want to fight for a fairer future. I commend the efforts of young people across the country and their engagement in grassroots action to ensure that their voices are heard. But there is still so far to go. Demonstrations are ongoing, because we aren't seeing action on the climate crisis. Australian students are being saddled with ever-increasing debt, and the leaders they are looking to do not seem to have the political will to take the actions we so desperately need.

Lowering the voting age to 16 would give young people the opportunity to have a real say over the politics and policies that will impact them for the rest of their lives. It would force elected representatives to be accountable to the young people they represent and would give young people a say in our democracy—a say they have clearly demonstrated that they deserve. Lowering the voting age isn't just important to ensure that young people's voices are heard, though; it's important for the future of our democracy. The last federal election had a historically low rate of voter participation, with voter turnout falling to below 90 per cent for the first time since the introduction of compulsory voting. The Australian compulsory voting system is one that we should be proud of. We give every citizen not just the right but also the responsibility to have a say in who represents them in parliament.

But as engagement with our voting system continues trending downward, it is important that we take proactive steps to increase participation. Examples from around the world have shown that lowering the voting age to 16 has resulted in increased participation, not just in those first two years of voting but throughout the voter's lifetime. The Scottish independence referendum, for example, saw 16- and 17-year-olds turn out to vote in higher numbers than their older counterparts. Germany has now decided to lower the voting age to 16 at the federal level after seeing positive outcomes at various state levels. States that had a voting age of 16 saw higher participation rates in democracy as these cohorts aged, versus states that had a voting age of 18. Increasing participation would mean that we could address the scale of the crises our country faces today. It would give those who will inherit the future that we in this place decide a say in who represents them.

I want to say thank you to the grassroots organisers who have been campaigning on this for many, many years, some of whom are in the building today. I look forward to seeing some of you sitting down here in the future.

Young people are desperate to make their voices heard. Expanding voting rights to 16- and 17-year-olds to give them true representation in this place is not only the least we can do for them; it's a political inevitability.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Chandler-Mather: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
Debate adjourned.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Nuclear Energy
Dr GILLESPIE (Lyne) (10:08): I move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:

(a) Australia has been at the forefront of nuclear science and technology since 1953 when the Australian Atomic Energy Commission was established and operated two research reactors at Lucas Heights in Sydney;

(b) since the Australian Atomic Energy Commission became the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation in 1987, it has operated the HIFAR Research Reactor, and subsequently the OPAL Research Reactor, which has delivered significant benefits for nuclear medicine in Australia and around the world;

(c) Australia has developed one of the world's leading regulatory and safety authorities to oversee the operation of its nuclear industries with the establishment of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency; and
(d) Australia is a signatory to international non-proliferation treaties which is overseen by the Australian Safeguards and Non-proliferation Office;

(2) considers the deployment of nuclear energy to deliver energy security for the nation, as part of Australia's transition to a decarbonised electricity grid, utilising emerging nuclear technologies such as Generation III+, Generation IV Small Modular Reactors and Micro Modular Reactors; and
(3) further considers the following legislative actions:
(a) removing the blanket prohibition on:

(i) the Minister for Environment and Water declaring, approving, or considering actions relating to the construction or operation of certain nuclear facilities as described in sections 37J, 140A and 146M, and paragraph 305(2)(d) of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, by repealing those provisions; and
(ii) the construction or operation of certain nuclear facilities as described in section 10 of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998, by repealing that section; and
(b) leaving unaffected:

(i) the other elements of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, pursuant to which the Minister would assess any application to establish a facility previously named in the repealed provisions;
(ii) state and territory powers to protect their citizens and the environment from potential adverse radiation impacts; and
(iii) the power vested in the Minister for Foreign Affairs to determine whether or not to issue a permit under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 for such a proposed facility.

During the 33 years I practised as a hospital doctor, from a junior intern through to a general internal medicine specialist, and for the last 22 years as a gastroenterologist, I and all the medical staff around me often used the miracle of modern medicine which utilises nuclear technology, including radionucleotide isotopes for iodine, technetium, molybdenum, X-rays or CAT scans, to diagnose and treat many conditions and, in many instances, cure cancers: breast, prostate, bowel, lung, brain or bone cancer and lymphoma; even overactive thyroid conditions use radioactive isotopes to calm the thyroid down. Yet, even though Australians and people around the world beg for, and wish that they had access to, that sort of technology and are happy to receive it, in Australia we have a schizoid response. When we apply to use the wonder that nature gave us of fission—of partially enriched uranium isotope 235—to boil water to very high temperatures and pressures, just like a coal-fired power plant does, and when we use that to run turbines which run electrical generators, like we have in all our coal plants or in hydro stations, people react, and we have legacy legislation prohibiting its exact use.

Why is it that people baulk? I think, having studied the psychology of this for many years, it's because people have had a trained emotional response because of the legacy fears about nuclear Armageddon as a result of the nuclear arms race. They've been misinformed or misled about what a powerplant is. A simple explanation is that it uses the wonders of fission with electrical rods that, when they get to a critical mass, heat up. The phenomenon of fission makes a lot of heat, just like the element of an old-fashioned kettle—you see those things around the ceramic base heating the water. Well, that's what happens in a nuclear power reactor, and that is enriched uranium—up to 4.9 per cent.

Mr Speaker, I want to reassure you that it is quite different from a nuclear bomb. A nuclear bomb needs 95 per cent enriched uranium—about 12 kilos of it—clustered in a little space, surrounded by huge amounts of physical explosive. There is no way a nuclear power reactor will ever become a nuclear bomb. Fukushima wasn't a nuclear bomb; it was a hydrogen gas explosion resulting from the intense heat because the cooling water stopped circulating. It wasn't a nuclear bomb. The Fukushima earthquake and tsunami killed 35,000 people. No people died from radiation exposure in Japan—not one, zippo, none.

But I will continue. Australia is already a nuclear-ready nation. We have operated three nuclear reactors for many years—since the 1950s in fact. We still operate the OPAL reactor in Lucas Heights, which is surrounded by suburbia where houses sell for $3 million, and no-one bats an eyelid. We have 1,300 people employed in nuclear and scientific activities within ANSTO. We have the Australian Safeguards and Non-Proliferation Office, which monitors our compliance with all the nonproliferation treaties around the world. We have ARPANSA, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, which is a world-class institution. Australia is a part of the International Atomic Energy Agency. We are a part of the fourth-generation nuclear power plants forum, called the Generation IV International Forum, which is researching and designing fourth-generation reactors. These are the newer and latest models, which will come into being in the next 10 or 15 years.

I've visited Canada and America and I've looked at some of these new, small modular reactors that everyone's talking about. They are ready to roll. They are going through final licensing. They're not some far-off, distant development. They are a mini version—refined. Just like a Volvo car, the latest models are incredibly safe. They have lots of passive and safety features. Like the current mobile phones, they're quite different from the big bricks that you used to have to carry around as the first mobile phones. They're smaller and more powerful and they are safe. They have passive safety, and they won't be analysed until we remove the prohibitions in the ARPANS Act— (Time expired)
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Pitt: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

Mrs PHILLIPS (Gilmore) (10:14): I will always rise to set the record straight when it comes to the Liberals' and Nationals' obsession with nuclear power. All I can say is that I'm so glad to stand here today as the member for Gilmore and as part of the Albanese Labor government, because this is the best assurance our community on the New South Wales South Coast can have against a nuclear reactor endangering our community and putting our pristine Jervis Bay at risk of harm.

That is what the Liberals and Nationals would do if they had the chance and if our community—with me standing with them, I am proud to say—didn't tell them each and every time they bring it up, 'No, we will not accept it.' That's what we do every time this obsession of theirs is raised. We point out, as I will again now for the member for Lyne and anyone else in the coalition ranks who needs to hear it, that nuclear is not an option. I know that the Liberals and Nationals don't seem to care about the inherent risk this would place our community in. They don't seem to care about the inherent risk to our farmers and farming land, or the risk to our health or our tourism industry. They don't seem to care about the risk it will place on our beautiful Jervis Bay Marine Park, our environment and our native wildlife. That much is clear, or we wouldn't still be having this conversation.

So let's talk in a language the Liberals might understand. The coalition are constantly banging on about bringing down the cost of energy. They say nuclear is the way to do that, but it has been proven that the costs of nuclear power do not stack up. The CSIRO continues to state that nuclear energy would far and away be the most expensive form of energy in this country. Nuclear energy produces less power now than 10 years ago, while wind and solar continue to grow. The capital cost of nuclear energy per kilowatt hour has increased, not decreased. A report from 2020 states:

… the costs of renewables continue to fall due to incremental manufacturing and installation improvements, while nuclear, despite over half a century of industrial experience, continue to see costs rising.
'What report is that from?' I hear you ask. It's from the World nuclear industry status report. Even the nuclear industry admits that it doesn't stack up.

In the last parliament, the Standing Committee on the Environment and Energy held an inquiry into nuclear energy. I sat on that inquiry, and we heard from expert after expert who said the same thing: there is no evidence for nuclear energy in Australia. Dr Ziggy Switkowski, a nuclear physicist and Chancellor of RMIT, told the committee that there is 'no coherent business case to finance an Australian nuclear industry'. There is simply no evidence that nuclear energy could or would bring cheaper power to Australia. What do all the experts agree can bring cheaper power to Australia? Renewable energy. Wind and solar. Cleaner, cheaper power is in renewables. But the Liberals and Nationals must have had their fingers in their ears during that inquiry, because the message still has not sunk in. So here I am, once again standing up for our community.

I was highly amused recently when the Liberals on the South Coast whipped themselves into a frenzy about fantasy wind project proposals. We have no wind industry on the South Coast, so there is no conversation yet to be had on these or any other projects. That didn't stop them trying to drum up hysteria, though. They said they are worried about the potential look and about the potential noise. What did I hear were whispers of the solution? Nuclear power instead. Apparently, if tourists were to come to Kiama to see our famous majestic blowhole, they would rather see a nuclear reactor blocking their view than some wind turbines off in the distance. It beggars belief.

Once again, I will promise this to the people of the South Coast: I will always stand in the way of anyone who thinks our beautiful coastline can be muddied with a nuclear reactor. I will stand with each and every person, farmer, business owner and conservationist who knows that nuclear power can only do more damage than good in our community. I say to the Liberals and Nationals, both here and on the South Coast, who continue to tout this as a solution to our country's energy needs: we will oppose you at each and every opportunity. We will not have nuclear power on the South Coast—not now, not ever.

Mr PITT (Hinkler) (10:18): The blackout specialists are at it again over there. The problem with their proposal is it doesn't work. That is clear to anyone that was in Queensland and saw the loss of power to entire suburbs with blackouts over the weekend. We have seen load shedding across industry because what they are proposing doesn't work.

Mr Speaker, I refer you to an incredibly good article by Claire Lehmann in the Australian on 3 February: 'The clean energy revolution hides a very dirty secret'. It's based on facts. The proposal from those opposite is some two million hectares of solar across this country—a product which lasts maybe, on average, 20 years, so every 20 years it has to be replaced. I've had reports of a new solar farm at Gympie, which still isn't connected, that lost 20 per cent of its panels—100,000 panels—in a hailstorm over Christmas. In Ms Lehmann's article, she says that in China alone waste from solar panels would add up to 20 million tonnes of waste, 2,000 times the weight of the Eiffel Tower, by 2050, and Australia will accumulate one million tonnes of solar panel waste by 2047.

We hear all of the scare campaigns and the scare tactics from those opposite. It's all about the half-life. I can tell you: heavy metals don't have a half-life. They don't expire. They're there forever. They are in these parts and they have to be dealt with. These are the points that we continue to make. It is about facts. Ms Lehmann's article also identifies:
… nuclear reactors have produced 390,000 tonnes of spent fuel since the 1950s, solar panels are estimated to create 78 million tonnes of hazardous waste by 2050, 200 times the amount …
A technology that has been in place for decades.

Those opposite say that there is no place for nuclear in Australia, it's a terrible solution and it's awful, but that's not what they say in the United States, France, the UK, South Korea, the UAE or anywhere else that is using this technology, because it works. It is consistent. If you want something which is zero emissions and will last for decades, this is an opportunity for Australia to look at it.

In the United States—once again back to facts—they produce about 2,000 metric tonnes of spent fuel every year. That sounds like a significant amount, but it is incredibly dense, which means it is very heavy by volume. That is the equivalent of less than half an Olympic swimming pool to power more than 70 million homes, and it avoids more than 400 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions. That sounds like a pretty good solution to me. In fact, the fuel can be recycled. It has more than 90 per cent of its potential energy still remaining in fuel after five years of operation in a reactor. That is straight from the United States Department of Energy. So if we're going to have a debate about this, let's make it about facts. Another example: in South Korea, nuclear energy will account for 34.6 per cent of South Korea's electricity generation by 2036. It can be done.

If you wish to have zero emissions in this country from energy generation, you've got until 2050, yet those opposite propose to destroy industry in this country by driving up the cost of power. We saw interventions from them before Christmas, which are now reportedly going to cost some $1 billion dollars in subsidies for the coal sector, let alone for gas. And guess what? There's no gas to offer, because no gas company actually knows what their costs are. How do you offer a long-term contract on a product when you don't know what the government of the day are going to do in their mandatory code of practice and other changes?

We hear about wind as well. Here's some information from the Parliamentary Library on wind and waste: each blade can be between 25 and 100 metres long. It is expected that by 2050 a total of 43 million tonnes of wind turbine blade waste alone will be produced and accumulated around the globe—43 million tonnes!—93 per cent of which is a composite material which simply cannot be easily recycled. In fact, no-one has found a solution for that at all.

The proposal from those opposite is to have our energy systems rely on the unreliable; to rely on the weather; to accumulate literally millions of tonnes of waste right around the country, but particularly in Australia; and to level, clear and cover over two million hectares of this country with what is the equivalent of a giant tarpaulin that has to be replaced every 20 years. This is nonsense; it's the reason it won't work. Sun Cable are now in administration. Why? Because, as the front page of the Australian reported, one of the proponents said it was not technically feasible—yet those opposite are suggesting that we can run solar energy from Cairns to Melbourne and it would be technically feasible. (Time expired)
